reviews.review: A true local market. This is a local market as you would find one in Lima or Arequipa but as you can find literally anything here, it is an absolutely must-do / must see.You can find cloths, food, meat, vegetables, herbs, chicha, .... name it you find it.Stroll around and enjoy the sound, smell, aromas and don't forget to take a fresh fruit juice

True Peruvian flavor. This place is very cool! The juice vendors and the food counters! We had a 2 course meal of fresh Peruvian food and a drink for a total of 10 sol. We left very full and satisfied. This is a great place to get souvenirs as the vendors are there to help but they don't harass you like the Plaza des Armas. So many things to see and try.

A photographer's dream!. This is one of the most diverse and lively markets I've seen, with everything from food to clothes to sundries being sold. The sections for breads and cheese are extensive, and there are also a couple of casual sit-down restaurants to get a cheap meal. A feast for the senses!

A sight to see!. We visited the market as part of a private tour of Cusco. Just a short walk from the main square. So much to see - it is a feast for the eyes! We stopped for a glass of fresh juice- delicious! If we had more time we would have returned for a more leisurely visit
Fun and diverse. This is a delight of sights and sounds. It's fun to see the mountains of goods. Negotiated a great deal on a sweater for my daughter. They have everything from toys to food.

Lively and interesting! . We loved this market. We ate here on a few occasions, food is cheap and cheerful. The juices and smoothies were delicious and the ladies very friendly and chatty. We bought fruit, nuts, oats, eggs etc. here and it's great value, all very fresh too. A great spot to visit!

Cheap local eats. Chicken soup...fresh fruit juice...cheese...and many more local cheap stuff... you can expect to pay less than 5sol for food.Handcraft here are cheaper than those stores around the main plaza. Bargaining is a must!!

A huge variety of products!. Some people say that something you can.'t miss when you visit a town is to visit its market and this is a very colorful place full of all kinds of products. As a peruvian I have visited many markets in my city but going to this one in Cuzco was more than I ever expected. So many new products to see, herbs, cheese, traditional bread, flowers, meat, etc, I was also surprised by the big number of stands that serve traditional dishes and cheap prices, locals eating there and many nice people working at the market.
Must see. Everything is for sale here, from souvenirs to fresh fish, meat, cheese, fruit juices and complete meals. Great experience.

Cow's snout anyone?. Great place where all kinds of fruit, meat, herbs, spices are sold and eaten in seamingly make-shift stalls! Real people doing real business. Just wander around and try some stuff you like, the food is conveniently organised by category. A little downside is that the tourist stalls with their completely indistinctive offerings are also present and taking more and more space. The road from the centre to the mercado is nice as well, with its gate and less polished shops.

Great local market with fair prices . If you're going to be staying in Cusco for a while and you want to cook yourself a meal the San Pedro market is the place to go to get your ingredients. The market is decently clean and there is a huge variety of vendors selling every fruit/veg/meat you can imagine. There are also many handicraft sellers in the market if you are looking for souvenirs. The market is only a 5 minute walk from the plaza de Armas and is well worth a visit.

Best place to shop in Cuzco!. You can find anything at the San Pedro market....from food to clothing to household items. Get all your souvenirs for family and friends. The people are friendly, always eager to help you find what you want, and always ready to bargain. Be sure to haggle a little as it's expected and they do tend to call a higher price initially. It is also centrally located and easy to find from the Plaza de Las Armas.

One of my favourite places in Cusco. A bustling & popular market in Cusco centre, with a huge range of souvenir, produce & food stalls. I recommend grabbing a made-to-order fruit juice from one of the many stands as you enter & also visiting Mari’s food stand (#837) at the back of the market for delicious cheap food. I wasn’t sure how easy it would be to find a veggie-friendly lunch, but Mari was really welcoming & made me a plate of her ‘Super Vegetariano’ dish fresh to order - rice, salsa, fries, plantain, avocado, grilled cheese & banana chips, all for less than £2! A great place to wander round, soak up the atmosphere & look at the impressive (& sometimes unusual) range of produce on offer. While you’re here, make sure you get some Peruvian specialties – plenty of stalls sell corn, chocolate, chia seeds, maca, quinoa etc. & grab some fresh lucuma & cherimoya from one of the fruit stands.

Sit down for a glass of juice. Loved it here. Right past the Arch of San Francisco, a quick walk from the main square. The first thing you'll see when walking in are the rows and rows for fresh juice. Do yourself a favor - order a refreshing, fresh juice and sit down to relax. They have stools all over the place for you to take a load off, people watch and enjoy the best juice you'll ever drink.After you're refreshed, the rest of the market is filled with clothes and art, souvenirs and gifts. In the very back, you'll see plenty of places to have another seat with a very healthy serving of glorious soups and other beautiful dishes. Enjoy!

Plan to spend 2 hrs ! . Just a few blocks from Plaza del Armas , this market has just about everything. Fresh flowers, textiles of every design , sweaters , teas, chocolates, and 2 Aisles of Fresh Smoothies.. choose yr favorite combo .. carrot, pineapple, orange, mango .

Good for lunch . The market is not that great in terms of stalls and variety of products. They sell the same things as everywhere else. However one thing that is really good about the market is the many food stalls serving cheap set lunches which are available for between 5-10 soles. I recommend only getting food that has been boiled or fried as hygiene doesn't seem to be cared for.
A Must See!. A great place to buy souvenirs and eat lunch. Try the food stalls! You will not be disappointed. And so cheap! A full meal for about 5 Soles.

Best Source for Souvenirs, Obligatory Gifts, Indigenous Dining. Happened to be in the immediate area during one of Cusco's infrequent rainstorms. The mercado is reasonably watertight. It is divided into a central area of 2 or 3 lengthy corridors that demarcate the "food court," a periphery of stalls that offer soft goods, and additional rows of other assorted merchandise perpendicular to the "food court." Remarkable was the fact that although there was an enormous volume of raw foods (butchered, but unwrapped, meats, poultry, fish), cheese, breads, cakes, there were no flies on the foodstuffs. Perhaps it is the altitude. If you are an adventurous gastronome, with access to cooking utensils, there were amny intriguing offerings. If you do not seek unnecessary labor, you could sit at any of many cafes, and dine with the locals. Prices, both for meals (mainly rotisserie chicken, sopas, and fish) and souvenirs are quite reasonable. Haggling is an expected behavior. The mercado is great fun for an hour or so.

local/touristic. Easy to find a few blocks from plaza de armas .Large building with tons of food ,fresh squeezed fruit drinks , cheese, meats.Quinoa,nuts & several stalls preparing meals. Very social gathering around a meal.plus tons of touristic items,backpacks, bags,t shirts,key chains, mugs, you name it Peru paraphernalia.we where warned by several locals that the was a lot of pick pockets there.We had no trouble.Picked up a few items and enjoyed the colours,sights, & smells of the San Pedro market
Should go. If you loke to understand the native culture that you are visiting it is a place that should be visites! I thought that amazing and very interesting!
Fun. Good place to have fun, enjoy peruvian culture, buy some groceries and souvenirs at low prices... Full of color!

Pretty good market. This market was fun to explore but I must say, after being around most of Peru, it is NOT cheap. Of course it's cheap if you're a westerner but compared to the rest of the markets in , say, Arequipa, Lima and other most other cities, you'll likely be paying more here than the others. Still not overly expensive and good as a one stop shop for all your souvenirs (and cheaper food) but if you're looking for the best deals the this is not the place.

A market you have never seen before!. Markets are great to experience culture. Locals are doing there grocery shopping, eating the breakfast and are haggling for the best and lowest prices. This market is no exception and a must visit while visiting Cusco. It is situated in the centre of the city and can be seen in less than an hour. You'll be amazed by the things they are selling and how products including vegetables and meats of all kinds are presented. Personally I have seen quite some market but this market knew how to trigger my senses in different ways. They offer great fresh juices which I highly recommend. If you have a strong stomach and if you are adventurous enough you could join the locals for either breakfast, lunch or dinner! This market is also a great spot for photographers. A tip would be to either take pictures on longer range, or kindly ask to take pictures. They might ask for a contribution, 1 sol is the usual amount to pay.

Amazing. Cultural. Must see. Awesome market. Highlight of my entire trip in Peru. Food, clothing, desserts, spices and seeds. Anything you could ever want is here. It shows the culture of cusco. Women are tailoring clothing in the entrance and then the typical vendors selling the fabrics and bags. Amazing fruit, meat, but stands. Cute dessert and breakfast booths. Not very clean inside at all but so rich with culture.

Awesome market...has it all!. Really enjoyed this traditional city market. Ridiculous mountains of fruit...all kinds. Great local specialties throughout...nuts, chocolate, keepsakes and all the usual fish, meats and produce one would expect. Some reviewers are wary about the hot food stalls but I ate my way through the place without a problem...special shout out to the "chicken soup lady"...you can't miss her little stall due to the tightly packed locals squatting on plastic stools while other similar stalls are uncrowded. The soup was absolutely fabulous...loaded with tender chicken, veg and noodles with an optional spicy onion/pepper garnish...the flavor and quality are unmatched...and all for 6 soles!!!One of the very best lunches we had in the whole country.Overall, a fun, fascinating and filling afternoon!

Great market, especially for food. We spend some good times here during our stay in Cusco. We bought fresh fruit, vegetables, cheese and nuts. Don't miss the cheap Brazil nuts only 2 soles for 100g of the 'broken ones' ;-)
Good experience. Walking around the market was a good cultural experience and definitely something to do in Cusco but it wasn't the cleanest place so maybe avoiding eating there.

Bustling market but not the cleanest place. This is a typical market in South America, where you can get pretty much everything.There are tons of different stalls though they tend to be grouped according the their specialty.It is a crowded place and I would not recommend people eating here unless you have a bullet proof stomach or have been here for a while (you will see meats and chickens as well as fish and cheeses seating on the heat for long time along with roaming dogs in the same area).It is a place to buy cheap crafts. No alpaca or baby alpaca sold here. No silver here either (it is a similar alloy called alpaca)

Vacation. Crowded, and beware of pickpockets, but otherwise a great place to buy souvenirs, We had done our teenagers souvenir shipping from regular touristy places, and found the exact same things for a fraction of the prices, we ended up getting more things just because they were so cheap, the shopkeepers all spoke broken English so we could bargain with them and got even better deals.

You Want it? You Got it!. This Mercado has “everything” a shopper wants and needs. Starting with clothing, handicrafts to the actual fruits, vegetables, meats, herbal items and magic potions. The meats, including the famous Cuy (the pig) are all found here. Even if you do not want to buy, you can get around and be entertained just watching everything! Some of the items found (meat) include vats of fruit juice, roast lechon (sucking pig), tamales, pig head for soup, tamales and many other items. You will truly be entertained.

Best place for local items. We did not get to eat at the market, so we just shopped around. It is very similar to a farmers market- mostly fresh produce, a food court, and clothing. There were lots of alpaca sweaters to choose from and relatively cheap - you can definitely bargain. I love visiting farmers markets in other countries because you get a great sense of the people and culture. Worth a visit! Why 4 stars? It is very crowded... I wonder what time of day is best to avoid crowds.

Local Experience. San Pedro Market is a hub for locals (and visitors) to gather and buy produce, meats, and other goods. It's a bustling, crowded place with loud corridors and a variety of products. You could spend a few hours walking it, and it's surrounding plaza. I got mixed opinions from locals on whether or not tourists should eat the food there. I'd already gotten sick once, so didn't risk it myself. But would probably give my stomach a few weeks to assimilate beforehand.

Amamzing place for juice, food and produce.. The central market in Cusco is a veritable mix of fresh produce, juice bars, local food and souvenir shops. We stopped by most days to have breakfast juices and/or lunch at one of the many stalls. The ceviche is tasty and we love the different fish. If your on a budget you'll live here, if your not stick your head in and enjoy the atmosphere.

A place that never disappoints me . As I do as a ritual every time I go to Cusco is visit this market.Most of tourists go to have a very interesting tour: taking pics of fruits and regular life in Cusco. In my case, I go shopping from bread or cheese for family and friends and mostly, I go to drink fresh fruit juice.For less than one and a half dollar (the cheapest one) you can have almost three pitchers of juice. The most expensive one (about four dollars) contains Malta beer (Cusquena of course, we are in Cusco!!!!) so this kind of juice is a super power one!Well, the market is divided in categories, so it's and interesting place to hang out. It never disappoints you!!!

Bargain, Buy Local, and Experience the Open Market. This market is large, colorful, active, and offers everything from food to flowers to clothing. The market opens early and winds down in the late afternoon. This market offers a chance to experience Cusco, take pictures, enjoy "Peruvian home cooking" at a kiosk, and ask questions. If you like bargaining, you can get items for 1/2 of the retail price. I will post some pictures of the different areas; there is an area for clothing, alpaca blankets (very nice), fruits, nuts, meats, fish, flowers, teas, coffees, sweets. Immerse yourself in Cusco.

Awesome chicken noodle soup and fresh juice. Organised into different sections/rows, the market has it all- from fresh produce to cheap tourist knick-knacks. The fresh fruit juice was a delicious. I highly recommend the chicken noodle soup (free soup and noodle refill!)! We saw locals and tourists eating there so had no problems trying it out. The 'chilli' garnish (what we would call salsa) was very tasty!

Local market. If you like local markets this is the one for you. There are the most amazing set of ladies selling fresh fruit drinks prepared before your eyes, great value and great taste. The rest of the market is all fresh food- meat, cheese, veg, fruit. Anything you could want. Plus the Peruvian equivalent of a food court. Great place just to wander round and take in the local sights.

A must visit Market. A must see when you come to Cusco. I believe this is the largest market in Cusco, and certainly has a fabulous selection of foods and souvenirs at excellent pries. On Saturdays the market is more oriented to locals, but still worth the visit. Keep your stuff close at all times!

You gotta visit the market - huge and bustling with loadsa cooked food options. Pretty big place. Probably 50+ ready food vendors, plus all the fresh food vendors. Also clothing/souvenirs. Its a good place to come for lunch. Recommend!

Authentic and cheap market frequented by locals!. One of our favorite activities in Cusco! A huge market truly for the locals, with stalls selling everything from local ingredients (including freshly severed cow heads - not for the squeamish!) to some cheap tourist fare (the cheapest you'll find in Peru!). Avoid buying anything near the Plaza de Armas and just come here instead! It was incredibly interesting to see the local produce and meat products, which are organized into categorized rows. One of our favorite areas was the juice stands, where you can get fresh juices for a few soles. Don't walk away after you finish your cup - you get 1 or 2 refills!
Great food! . Go here for a good and inexpensive meal. The row with fresh made juices was a favorite. Also possible to buy various souvenirs.

This is a Cusco highlight.. This was definitely one of the most interesting stops in any of the urban centers I visited while in Peru. You can learn a lot about a culture by checking out their local foods. This place is huge. You'll find meats, vegetables, herbals, textiles, shamanic goods, tourist trinkets, flowers, etc etc. If you are able, I recommend a guided tour. Lots of stories and info behind the goods you are looking at.

What do the locals eat with a side of souvenirs. Nice little market which has all the juice, meats, cheeses, nuts, and souvenirs you want. There is also a health section to fix any aliments. Not that i tried any, but it's a good free tourist attraction to look. Make sure to see Shirley at stall 81, she makes a mean juice and gives a great conversation.

See the locals. Visited during a Sunday afternoon so some stalls were closed up. There are plenty of souvenir stalls but of greater interest are the food stalls. Fresh juices with fruits we weren't familiar with but all delicious. Always interesting to see how cultures sell their food and how they sell it. Stall holders are not very keen to talk to you, even with a fluent spanish speaker. It is the experience.

Must see in Cuzco. The Mercado Central de San Pedro is one of the best and most traditionally authentic markets that I have been to in South America. It is unique in that it contains both trinket shops and food in one place, so you can experience real-life Cuzco all at once. Even if you do not buy anything, it is worth it just to walk around. You can tell that it is not just a tourist spot- many Cuzco residents go to the market for their every day needs. While there is a huge section of stands that serve food for very cheap prices, if you are a foreign traveler (especially from the US) I would not recommend eating there, simply because such places can make unaccustomed travelers quite sick. Regardless, it is a must visit for anyone passing through Cuzco!

Almost all you or the local population could want.. The San Pedro market offers a huge variety of goods in a presumably well managed jumble of stalls selling clothes, fish, bread, meat, fresh juices, chicken meals,flowers, the usual international mix of tourist tat, etc. Many in local farming dress and some life stories in the faces of the aged. A good way to experience some of the local produce and culture, as in many parts of the world.
Very interesting market. Almost anything you eat in Cuzco will come from here. Might as well look at your meal while it is covered with flies. Friendly staff will explain the operation.
a must see. the market is 5 min from the square. there are many sights to see there! the fruit smoothies are good.. also try the corn with cheese.. and we bought cheese and bread and nuts for lunch

Okay to spend a few hours of your day. Huge local market with a variety of different goods for sale. Meats, vegetables, fruits, flowers, section of food stalls, etc. Easy to walk to from Plaza de Armas. We took a taxi from Plaza San Blas only because they had all the roads closed and blocked on Friday the 24th because of the Inti Raymi festival and the cost one way was 6 Soles.I would recommend trying some fresh juices from one of the vendors, they are refreshing and so tasty and at 5-6 Soles, you cannot go wrong. We are pretty adventurous eaters and would have tried a bowl of the "Caldo de Pollo", which seemed the common food offered everywhere, but we were still pretty full from breakfast and skipped it. Just an FYI, especially for the ladies, bathroom situation is pretty nasty, they have a huge bathroom building outside, but they are those squatters holes. We walked quite a ways away from the mercado in search of a restaurant and I was lucky to find one that let me use their bathroom it wasn't that much better, but definitely an upgrade from the squatters.

San Pedro Market. This is a must see for those who are traveling in Cusco. This is a true marketplace for the locals. My group did not buy anything in the market place, but that was not from a lack of buying opportunities. The market is an easy walk from the central square even with children in the group.

Dynamic local market. The market is big. It contains different sections as fruit, vegetables, meat, cooked food, clothes, souvenir, etc. The fresh extracted fruit juice is delicious, and costs no more than 5 soles for two cups. Cooked food stall is crowed with locals. The food looks interesting, but I haven't dared to try one. The cloth and souvenir stalls are worth a visit. The first offered price is already at least 30% cheaper than the final offer I got from the shops in Sacred valley. Of course, the negotiation can reduce further the price. But generally speaking, I guess that it is hard to find any authentic local hand made souvenir without a very decent budget. The original packages of scarf, bags in the market show that they are made in China.

Very agressive sellers. If you visit Cusco, this is a must place to go. Many sellers. Small restaurants. Clothes. Food. Vegetables. Meat. Remember Cusco seller offer a first price , they are good negotiators. The first price is the initial offer it, then ask for a reduction. Leave the place to see other places and compare prices. Return and ask for a reduction, because is lower in other places. Then will agree. Do not buy the first price. There are places to eat cheap. But I do not recommend you to eat there. Only locals go.

Everything under the sun and then some.... This local market has 4 sections - the fruits/vegetable section, the fresh meat section, the food section and surrounding it the knick-knacks sections. The fruits/vegetables sections has a huge variety of goods - there are 3500 varieties of potatoes to start with! There are fruits from the jungle that I have not seen before, along with many recognizable tropical fruits. Roots, vegetables, tubers of all kinds - it is a riot of colors and smells for the senses.The fresh meat section is not for the squeamish - much like what one finds in Asia, freshly slaughtered meat is hung in open air, alongside innards, and heads of various animals. Can't have it any fresher?The cooked food section is apparently very popular for lunch with the locals - we did not try eating here. One popular dish is a stew cooked with the sheep's head - has a strong aroma to it, which is likely what one smells as one gets closer to the stalls. On the other side of the market though, are the fruit juice stalls where fresh fruit juices are extracted - delicious. One special drink consisting of a mix of "stuff", mainly fruits and root extracts and dark Malt Beer, called "especial con malta", is a popular drink for energy and health benefits. It may seem strange to mix malt beer (stout), with fruit juices, but it actually tastes pretty good - try it! But be forewarned that it is pretty filling and you are drinking beer even though diluted, so there is alcohol in the drink! But definitely worth trying and yumm!The last section is the section where they sell all sorts of knick knacks - good deals to be had if you are willing to bargain, and shop around. An interesting insight into what the local Cusco-ans eat, drink, buy especially if you can snag a local who will explain some of the "so called strange" (unknown) stuff to you.

Fun to Visit to Shop and Eat. A huge market that's almost a little overwhelming. Tons of clothes and food and restaurants and all sorts of souvenirs. Hard to haggle with the vendors though which I didn't understand based on my previous trips to markets in other countries--perhaps a misunderstanding on my part. Had a lot of fun just walking around and bought a fun hat but did not try any of the food, though there were so many cheap smoothie and food options!

Feel the local vibe. This market is a place to embrace the local culture, especially the food. A lot of different fruits, meats, and dishes are available. Have a nice tropical juice! very delicious and cheap.

Love this place!. We went here for breakfast almost every morning! Mostly locals and everyone is very friendly. There are tons of places to eat, from soups, to juices to ceviche. It was a great way to start off our days in Cusco!

Great mercado for shopping and eating. The San Pedro Central Mercado in Cusco is worth a visit. It's not far from Plaza de Armas. Between souvenir shopping and eating, we spent almost two hours at the Mercado on our first visit. And, we liked our lunch so much that we went back to the Mercado for lunch another day.  This local market sells food, fruits, flowers, clothes and souvenirs. Vendors are willing to negotiate prices for souvenirs. Prices are a little cheaper than at the Pisac market, but I'm not sure that the quality is better. But who can really tell how much alpaca is in a sweater or scarf.

One of the best experience in Cusco. This place really worth a visit! It is a proper market with various type of fruits, food, vegetable, fish, etc., but I liked this market more than any other I have seen in Peru or Bolivia. It is a great place to have there delicious and cheap lunch and also if you want to try best smoothie I can fully recommend it. Try smoothie place number 59, Rina, she was absolutely amazing, she even gave us free drinks during our second visit and was trying to speak with us all the time, even when our Spanish skills were really, really bad.

A must see!. I loved my time in the Mercado Central!! Be sure to stop and have a smoothie. One will easily serve two to three people. While some may be put off by the sights in the meat aisles, it gave me an appreciation for Peruvian nose to tail eating. Lots of shopping available for tourists. Shopkeepers here were much less aggressive than at the handicrafts market near the train station. Do yourself a favor and use the restroom in your hotel or at a restaurant prior to your visit to the market. The only restrooms available are public squatters.

Great spot for a visit. You can buy practically anything here. It is a busy place of commerce for locals with trading in all sorts including all types of protein and produce, flowers... They have lots of street food though I didn't try any. There are plenty of souvenir shops and they are much cheaper than most other places. My husband bought a hat here and the exact same hat was almost three times the price in Plaza de Armas. Wander through and see the weird, the wonderful and the rest of it.

Great place to visit-and Free. This is a working Mercado where the locals go to pay their food. Here you will see everything, from Fried Guinea Pigs, to more types of grain and fruit than you can identify, as well as local food counters were they provide the local food dishes for sale. Please be respectful of the shoppers and sellers. Perfect break from the rest of the tour spots.

Interesting market offering everything from fruit to meat to crafts. This was a fun stop during our time in Cusco. It's a proper market filled with fresh fruit, vegetables, fish and meat. You can buy dried fruit and nuts, too, which made for nice snacks while trekking. We visited at the end of the day, and I'd really recommend going first thing in the morning. The meat sits out on the counters all day and the smell was...interesting. Worth a stop to grab some snacks or cheap arts and crafts.
A highlight of Cusco!. We headed back into this market over and over - fresh fruit for breakfast, a quick 'street food' lunch, nuts and dried Inca berries for our Inca Trail trek. Recommended!
A must see!. The market was amazing to visit. You can find anything here! Make sure you try a juice from one of the juice ladies!

Great Souvenir Shopping. San Pedro Market is not far from my hotel Tierra Viva Cusco Centro. This local market sells food, fruits, clothes and souvenirs. I went there for shopping the souvenir. Here we can find Cusco Region including Machu Picchu souvenirs. The price is cheaper than in Machu Picchu market.

Good market!. A nice, well sectionised local market with lots of cheap and good food for lunch. Join the crowd! Just sit where the locals sit and don't hesitate to queue. The market closes around 5PM.
a place to choose a wide variety of fruits. if you like to eat natural, this is your placer...from simple juices to the most elaborated peruvian food at good prices and all fresh from the country.

Great Fun Shopping and Learning More About Local Culture. This is the third market we have been to on this trip and it is one of the best. You need to explore markets like this to really get the local color. Also there are plenty of photo opportunities as well as lots of souvenir shopping.

Fabulous Market!. Located not far from Plaza de Armas this market has everything!From artesanal clothing, souvenirs to little cafes where you can grab a bite to eat/drink to buying all the local produce including meat, fruit, veg, nuts, seeds etc!It's a fabulous market & the prices are great too - don't waste your hard earned pennies on buying souvenirs from anywhere else - save them & go to San Pedro Market - it's cheaper & you can definitely get a bargain or two!A must go to market whilst your in Cusco!

Great, cheap food and souvenir market. The San Pedro market has a souvenir area where you can buy essentially anything to bring home from Peru. It also has a food section which offers excellent basic meals at cheap prices. This is a great place to get a local bite, but not a good place for someone who wants a restaurant atmosphere, is looking for service, or wants anything fancy.

Great market!. Don't waste your money buying souvenirs and food (quinoa, chia, kiwicha, pecans...) in Lima or in any other place for that matter... This market has it all at a much better price! 12 soles for 1kg of red/black quinoa, 5 soles for 500g of white chia.... I can only say that I regretted not having bought more!

Get your souvenir shopping done under one roof. Take the stroll down avenida Del Sol to this swap meet type of environment with hundreds of different vendors. There is a lot of repetition in merchandise - Peruvian dolls, jewelry, blankets, sweaters, shoes, bags, purses, textiles, and all sorts of souvenir type trinkets. Basically the same things that are found all over Cusco under one roof and basically for the same price. Adult sweater 35-40 Sol, Childrens 25-30 Sol. But remember things are not authentic. They will say for example that the sweaters are alpaca, but they are actually acrylic. It's a great place to buy cheaper stuff if you want the look of Peru for less. Vendors are not too pushy to sell. If you are not interested, just say "maybe later," which is code for I'm not interested. I would recommend this place for souvenir shopping.

Cusco must see. The market is definitely worth visiting for anyone interested in seeing the local culture or buying local souvenirs. The variety of foods available in the food court offers a tasty treat

can't miss this market while in cuzco!. this incredible little market is the best place to buy everything! try exotic local fruits and amazing soups and juices, all at ridiculous prices! you can also buy magical implements at various shamanic stalls, including San Pedro cactus, mapacho cigs and even ayahuasca! the clothing here is also high quality and deals abound. friendly people here will help you, embrace you and give you directions to anything you need! even if it's a suitcase to take home all your stuff!

Cheapest and Best. You should be able to find anything you need at this place, and at the right price too (after a little haggling, of course). Natural fruit juices, clothes, souvenirs, dried fruit, meat, eggs, veggies, chocolate, frog legs, chicha... it's all there. Especially great is the local flavor; there are some tourists, but it's dominated by the locals and you can actually feel like you're getting some different culture.Also a great place to stop for lunch. 6 soles for a delicious menu? Yes please!

Don't miss a visit to this market. Amazing displays of every day life in Peru, anytime spent walking through this market will be rewarding. The displays and varity of fruits will impress and the prices are so cheap. Fresh fruit juices are a must to try. The variety of goods to buy is unlimited , we purchased leather hand bag, authentic costumes, braids and fruit. Certainly a highlight to experience .

Great place to find anything you need. You want cheap food, you get cheap food. You want clothes, you get clothes. There is everything in this market. It's one of the places where you really feel you're with the peruvian people. There is a lot of tourists too, but you can see when you enter that it's a place where locals go too.

the stomach of the town. a typical market where peruvians go for luch and gringos to drink a very healthy, i met one guide of qorianka who told me about the lares trek in his agency QORIANKA tours, i accepted and dont regret, it was the most thrilling & amazing tour of my visit hiking on faraway tracks, it was a nice service and very dependable.

Half Food, Half Crafts market. Lots of food options here. You can buy juices, Ceviche and LOTS of meats. They have all the body parts of many animals here for sale. There are also crafts stalls which pretty much all sell the same thing, same same but different. This place is definitely worth visiting. Oh FYI the same person who designed the Eiffel Tower also designed this building, he made it open so it wouldn't smell as bad.

Amazing place. Great if you wanna check locally products and have a cheap meal! Mine was 5soles in one of the street food stalls!You can find eeverything in the market!I did not enjoy that much the corridor where the butchers are though....very smelly!Amazing fresh pressed juices corridor!

Cusco: eat poquito, see and buy a lot. A Peruvian told me the rules for surviving the altitude in Cuzco: Comer poquito, caminar poquito, dormir solito" Eat little, walk just a little and sleep alone. Still, if you have enough air, you can't miss the market, because you see all the colours, the food, the people and the best prices for handcrafts. Among its niceties, you get signs in three languages: Spanish, English and Quechua.

I love Markets this one not so much. Crowded, Little Far and Smelly . I usually love markets but not this one, just a few shopping stalls, this market is big but almost everything is food. so If you are going craft shopping you better explore the streets of cusco (behind Plaza the Armas on the way to San Blas) much better.

Worth a visit, cheapest meals in town. El "mercado de san pedro" is a covered food/souvenir market next to San Pedro church. Here you can try a lot of different peruvian meals for the cheapest price in town. I m teavelling on a budget and i loved it. 5/6 soles (peruvian currency) for a soup and a first course, plus a glass of muña/coca leaves tea. Great! You can also buy grocery or peruvian souvenir. Don t miss it!

Everything you need.. Great local market with amazing sights and sounds. You can buy almost anything here at local prices -- cheese, chia seeds (US$ 2 for a large packet), quinoa, fruits and vegetables, juices, teas, alpaca sweaters, tourist tee-shirts and more. At the far end of the market are the meat sellers and there are some interesting sights to be seen there. Not for the squeamish though.Many locals can be seen buying groceries and having a meal there. Cooked food is available and there are benches you can sit and eat by the counters. Fruit juices seem to be a thing here. There are rows and rows of them.

Good market. Spent several hours at this market. Very easy walk from Plaza de Armas. It is the place where locals do their shopping and have breakfast and lunch. The Fruit drinks are freshly made and excellent. Worth visiting and enjoying the local flavor.

You have to be there to believe it. My husband and I always visit local markets - we feel that food represents culture and we love learning new things, how food is prepared and new ingredients to try. This market is not huge but very colorful and not a tourist trap. The locals shop here. I tried on a beautiful Peruvian hat and they did not have my size - while I walked to other stalls the vendor found one for me and traced me down with no pressure whatsoever and gave me great price! I also was looking for fresh nuts and dates and three of the vendors could not have been more helpful. Even if you don't speak Spanish a bit of pointing and tasting goes a long way!

Very tasty breakfast!. We had such a rewarding breakfast here! This is the perfect place to start your day. It has a very cultural feel and the food here is much more local and less tourist than we had anywhere else. Also, great prices. About 5-10 soles a meal.
Great Indoor Market. Large Indoor market area with various interesting food options, an emphasis on meats, cheeses and on fruits and plenty of fruit juices and smoothies to sample

Exotic Fruits! Local foods! And more.... I went here and tried exotic local fruit like Lucuma, Tuna(cactus fruit) & cherimoya(a different kind of custard apple from what we have in Asia. The market has everything from food, juices, grains, dairies, souvenirs, breads, etc. After we explore the market, we went outside to get emoliente, a traditional Peruvian drink believed to have some kind of health benefit. Recommended!

Incredible cheap eats and local culture. My sister and I went here two mornings in a row for incredible breakfasts. This isn't a super touristy place (although we didn't feel out of place) and it's a great place to watch locals doing their shopping and getting a bite to eat. There are little stalls where you can sit and get food cooked for you while you wait (get the hot chocolate!) and an incredible area with juice bars. Even though I was careful about eating raw produce in Peru, the juices are made fresh without water from peeled produce and we were fine drinking it two days in a row. Come hungry!
Wonderful local market with products ranging from fruits to hats. Very nice market, offering cheap food and souvenirs and clothes. Also good to take photos. Definitely go there:)

A real market.....Must visit.. This is a must visit market in Cusco. We had a fresh squeezed juice in these markets....A great start...Walk around and feel like a local. We went with a guide who showed us around........It is busy so carry gear safely.

Festive adventure for your eyes and stomach!. Markets tend to be very vibrant and exciting places for certain "2nd world" countries and this is definitely a gem of a market place!I recommend u visit the market early on in your visit to Cusco for many reasons.As the start of this review mentioned...its exciting! This place is filled with food stands that serves local dishes for cheap, and stores that sells local produce. Very colorful and full of aroma! You get to sit down with locals and tourists alike and order a dish from visual displays from one of the many food vendors. Try a cerviche stand and watch how they put together this "fish salad" dish! Ingredients are all put out in the open in plastic containers and the market place isn't the cleanest place in the world...dont come here if u only tolerate restaruantsAfter a meal and u explore the rest of the market and check out some fresh produce u can try. I recommend everything from the fresh fruits, nuts, bread, and even quinoa if u got cooking ultilies in ur accomodation. Eating and buying from the market is definitely your thing if ur on a budgetYou can also wander the streets surrounding the market building itself as the area is one big market area. There is some desert/sweets vendors on one of the streets that u can find easily. Some of the cakes looked REALLY good and dirt cheap tooone big WARNINGDont go to the toilet there. I'm an asian and dirty toilets aren't new to meBut that public toilet is horrendous. U pay 1-2pesos to use it and the place is probably the dirtiest place u can imagine. They even got a big plastic barrel filled with water that people wash from.TIP: go to the toilets before u make ur way to the market. Bring some hand sanitizerOtherwise the market was awesome!

Interesting, food, sourvenirs. come here to check out interesting produce, experience a large local market and buy the souvenirs you see all over the city at cheaper prices. Located close to the tourist centre of the city, adding this in to our day felt cultural, fun and very worthwhile.Note: bargaining by around 10% accepted

A great time to wander by yourself. By the way, some sections are not for the smell-sensitive. There is a section of cheeses, meats and chocolates, along with a clothing, fruit and eatery section. I got my backpack handle repaired there and my shorts mended for 2 and 1 sole, respectively.I went there for my final souvenir shopping and saw the best prices there. It also helped that I shopped a lot of goods at one stall and asked for a discount.Wander in there and spend some time looking if you're not in the mood to shop. Really colorful place.

So much fun. This a very worthwhile stop. Well, we always stop in public markets everywhere. Take the time to ask questions about things that are unique because they will love to inform you when you show an interest.

Shop around to avoid getting ripped off!. San Pedro Market is a great place to get souvenirs. (It’s not just food and fruit vendors). It was also open on a Sunday, when most other things are closed in Peru. (Though not all of the stalls were open)However, because the vendors know that their clientele is mostly tourists, many will quote you some pretty high prices. For example, I wanted one of those tiny alpaca magnets (that are probably made out of synthetic instead of actual alpaca). Everyone was quoting 2 soles, when I know for a fact that my friend bought them for one. It’s kind of exhausting, but I hate getting ripped off. Alternatively, you don’t need to go to San Pedro to get souvenirs. I found that poking my head through some courtyards near the Plaza del Armas was also good, and sometimes even cheaper. Everyone pretty much sells the same stuff, so just start searching early!

A Colorful Experience. The San Pedro Market was interesting to visit with all of the different stalls, we really enjoyed walking through the fruit area as there were many fruits that we had never seen or tried before. Lyle the owner of the B&B we were staying at was with us and purchased a few of the fruits to try with breakfast, theChirimoya was my favorite. Lyle also took us to a lady at the bottom (dining) area where we tried some doughnut like things called picarones, which were sweet and delicious, we were told that they are made from Pumpkin and sweet potato.

where the locals go to trade their crops. We were probably on the few tourists walking through this market. This is where the locals go to trade/sell their chickens, potatoes, grains with the locals. No bathrooms. Great for looking/tasting some fruits that you've never seen. Don't expect to buy anything here. Very interesting stop. Go with your guide and not alone!!

Fun place to stroll through and get authentic flavors of Cusco. An authentic market where the Cusco local folk buy a lot of their food. They have a number of food courts for eating food. It was relatively crowded when we were there on a weekday morning. Unfortunately I didn't have the time or the courage (or a strong stomach) to try anything here. I knew that I had to be careful about eating the fruits or probably even the fruit juices. There are a number of stalls for souvenirs, but the market did not seem to be a typical tourist trap. The San Pedro Market was a fun place to walk around and get a good idea of the culture of Cusco and Peru in general by experiencing the food and other supplies that are here for sale.

Large market with variety of stalls. The market is huge with both outside street vendors and inside stalls. There are a variety of stands selling flowers, cheese, meat, bread, fruits, chocolate, dried goods, etc. There is also a cafeteria in the back of the building.
This place is definitely worth a visit.

Local market. Central market in Cusco, you can walk from the Plaza de Armas. I went there for breakfeast a couple of times and the juices are worthed, they serve you more than one glass. You can also buy fruits, meat, spices...

Worth a visit. Its a place worth the visit. You can get delicious juices, souvenirs, food, etc. It´s the right place to see the daily life of the cusco people.
You can spend a morning or afternoon there. And it´s close to the main square.
Don´t miss it.

Absolute must visit . San Pedro market is simply a must see.It's a large covered market that has everything imaginable for sale. The sights and smells overwhelm your senses.From unrefrigerated butchery to florists, San Pedro cactus and mummified Llama foetuses to sweet and sticky cakes......every turn, every stall has something to see.Just remember as others have written, it's a working , living market not just a place for curious visitors....I loved it here. And, as it was on my door step so to speak I visited daily.I also wandered the market stalls set in the avenues and alleys of Belen, again a fantastic experience despite what you might read elsewhere. Take a few simple precautions, such as nothing in back pockets tips things and be mindful of pickpockets and you too will enjoy this area of Cusco.Just a final note. I spoke to a number of people who where horrified at the meat products for sale and the lack of refrigeration ....,I asked them where they thought the expensive restaurants around Plaza de Armus purchased their meat....,Tesco or Waitrose .

Incredible Market!. This market is in San Pedro neighborhood in Cusco. We walked from Plaza de Armas. It's a huge market, very worthwhile going. They have just about everything from spices, clothing, flowers, chocolate to cow's heads. It's a must see if you like markets and want a taste of culture. Highly recommend going.
Something for all the senses. Be prepared to experience shopping in a whole new way. Lots of stuff to see, smell, touch and taste!

Fabulous Market for food and provisions.. So many sellers. I tried the sweet empanadas from a sweet young girl who was working the stall with you adorable sister. Had such a great meal with the locals-the chicken is amazing in peru and a must try. for both cultural and food reasons you should visit for sure.

Must visit and experience but respect the locals re taking photos. We visited the markets a number of times. So much energy, so much to see, so much to buy or taste. The black corn was on our list to find. The store owner was marvellous in letting us take photos. Another great were the rows of juice stands. Ladies make and sell juice on order. We had one on each visit. The seafood is another must to experience
You can get anything you want - meals, ingredients fruit, veg, meat, breads. Great place to visit. If you are hungry eat in. Great colours of flours, veg. Tourist crap if you need it too.

Hard to believe the variety. An amazing variety of Corn, Potatoes, and Quinoa on display and it's all for sale. We visited on a Saturday and the place was packed with people shopping for their Sunday meals.
An interesting place to visit. This was our first visit we did in Peru. With our guide we saw nice interesting spots with varieties such as spices, vegetables, fruit and marvellous smoothies.

Small market, cheap food if you are brave enough to eat there! 😵. It's a good size market, I live in The Hague and we have a much bigger market. Some of the souvenir shops are cheap but you can find cheaper somewhere else. Go on Sunday mornings, it's full of locals who come to eat there after coming from the church. I did take breakfast there but it was bread and cheese and a cup of coffee. Very cheap! And if you like fresh juice go there. For 5 soles you get 3 glasses of fresh made smoothies! I used to go there every day, also to chat with the ladies. In a restaurant you pay 7 soles for 1 glass! I did buy some fruits and nuts but outside the market they are cheaper. Maybe because I am tourist that why I get charged double. Go to my friend Kathy for a smoothie, she is at the entrance of the market. And if you dare to eat there, meals are very cheap.

Quite a site. For Tourist and Locals.. A local market with many gifts, food, and items for both tourist and locals. Many stands for lunch or a fruit drink. A great culture experience in the center of the city.

Picturesque Cusco Market!. In this market you can find a great variety of things; many of them are not common in some other cities of Peru; and, of course, in the world. Once you're there, try some really fresh fruit juice; have a look at the different types of corns and potatoes; and much more!
Fresh Fruit!. Best place in town for fresh fruit. Anything you want or want to try......you can get it here! Also has a lot of trinkets great at this time of year for Xmas!

Ok - if it's the only market you gonna see in Peru. The market itself is big and has sections for souvenirs as well as normal everyday products and food. With a big focus on tourists the place feels a bit fake (it isn't). But you still get a glimps of how more normal markets elsewhere in the country look like. Good thing is that you find some goods (esp. food) cheap here. So pay this market a visit at least once while in Cuzco.

Bustling with Energy. Our tour guide brought us through the market and stopped at some stalls for a few demonstrations. It is the heart of the city and a fantastic place to pick up some food at the prices the locals pay.

Street food at its best. Cheap way to eat great food feeling like a local. One of the few markets in which it didn´t turned out to be a artisan flee market.Go for the food court in the back. I went for the Ceviches and later stopped by a sort of milky drink stand, which I knew after drinking to be a sweet quinoa-cinamon drink.
A little dark but the heart of the city. Best place to buy fruits/food and the cheapest place in town to lunch (5pen). We often took our breakfast there and even bought sandwichs for our treks

Interesting market. It's always very interesting to visit markets whilst travelling as it reflects the local culture and this one was no exception. I liked how they sectioned the food stalls so they all sold the same type of food, easy to see which type of food or which food stall is popular

Cultural Tour!. It has everything.. clothes, fruit & vegetables.. local cheese..You´ll get another percpective of the city. Go walking through all the passages. Could be an unpleassant experience to see the hanging pigs and meat and smell them.. but it won´t take too long if you walk fast.Some of the things you can do there: Have your clothes sewed.. drink a fresh juice for a ridiculously low price.. and ofcourse, have luch at one of the food places.

Mucha variedad de productos a muy buen precio / Excellent variety of products at very good price. I enjoyed very much buying fruits, fresh juice, having cheap lunchs, walking there is an experience itself

This is a must do!. A very interesting market with so many sights and smells. This market is open daily and is a feast for the senses. There are numerous vendors under one roof selling everything from tourist souvenirs (hats, scarves, key chains, wooden wares, ceramics, etc.) to pig heads. There is a wide variety of grains, fruits, vegetables, meats, breads, cheeses, as well as grocery type items like jam. We didn't sample the food, but there was plenty of opportunity to try the local soup or fresh juices. The "meat department" was interesting as there was a variety of fish, chicken, pork and not sure what else.Even if you don't buy anything it is a great way to spend a couple of hours simply wandering around looking at the different items and people.

A slightly more authentic view of Cusco than most of the downtown!. San Pedro market is within 5 minutes walk of the main square, and house stalls selling all sorts of stuff from touristy trinkets and clothes (of course) to fresh produce, bread etc together with rows of food stalls where locals eat cheaply across the day. (Be careful of the hygiene issues though if you are tempted!) On all sides of the market itself are street vendors selling all manner of things including more touristy tat for sure. As you drift down hill around the back of market, things really get interesting as you see street upon crowded street of curb side sellers peddling all sorts of fresh produce etc. This is perhaps more interesting, but also be mindful the streets are crammed with people, cars and vendors so the risk of the odd pickpocket may rise accordingly!Enjoy!

Great market. San Pedro market has a lot to offer.From typical tourist wares (at much better prices than Plaza De Armas) to a great place to get cheap traditional food (literally eat where the locals eat - soup for 2.5 soles) - it's worth the visit.

Definitely worth a visit to San Pedro Market. We visited after walking the Inca Trail, so we were comfortable in buying fruit, cheese, olives and bread. The prices were reasonable and we didn't need to do much bargaining.The market is grouped into aisles for various items ranging from flowers, bread, meats, beverages and even souvenirs. We were able to get our mementos at around 20% less than the shops closer to the main plaza de aramas.

Love, Love, Love this market. Every time I am Cusco I head to this market. It is one of my most favourite places to go in the city.They have a number of juice stands where ladies wave you in for a fresh juice. I always stop at the same stand - "Urbelinda". She's on the end. If you order a juice, just make sure you don't order the Combo Mixto (3/soles) as it comes with water which may not be good for your stomach. All others are pure fruit. I like the orange, maracuya & mango.There are also a lot of vendors selling everything from fruit to clothes to meat & cheese. Very interesting to see how the people of Cusco shop.In the back there is a food court of sorts where you can get very cheap food.Although I have never had an issue, make sure you keep your eyes open in the market and keep things in your inside pockets. As it is crowded, there can be pick-pocketing.

So exotic the shamanic booths are the best. This is the most wonderful place. I always get all my fruit, vegetables, bread and coca leaves here. It was named for the near bye church which was name for San Pedro Cactus. Which you can buy there..
Fun, to walk around and reminded me of markets in Mex. Just a regular market in Latin America. We walked around and purchased, salt, coffee and chocolates. We also had a freshly juiced drink, a must.
Small and Peaceful town. Great to stop by to see the traditional culture if you get some time. Pure and Quiet. Shopping for local food and souvenirs.

Interesting market to have some food and the best juices in the city!. If you have time I really recomend you to visit the market, you can eat very cheap and you can have a very good juice in the corresponding section.

Unique experience. Loved this market! This is where the locals shop. It is divided into sections and you can find everything there! Even bought a candle and lit it at a shrine there for my mom. You can easily spend a few hours there. No need to book a tour, taxis will take you. It only cost 4 sols from our hotel for four people. Get your fare negotiated up front. The local food served there is tasty. Have fun there! I found lots to buy.

Fun place to shop. We actually did 95% of our souvenir shopping here. It's a fun place to shop, people watch and drool over the selection of food! Unfortunately, my sensitive tummy does not allow me to eat market food but I did see many tourist eating at the stands and juice bars. Prices are excellent here for souvenirs. I walked away with knitted purses, bowls and hats.

Must see. Sept 18This was the first stop of the Cusco city tour. After a very good buffet breakfast with a la carte hot egg dishes, we left our well-located Hotel Palacio del Inka at 8:00 with our wonderful guide Jimmy and driver Alejandro.As others have mentioned, this market has everything you want from produce, food (eg, bowl of chix soup is 5 soles), souvenirs, and meats. I bought 1/2 kilo of Peruvian (Tunkimayo) coffee for USD$13.Of interest to me were prepared packages of gift offerings in the native offering, Pachamama, that worships Mother Earth and gives thanks for everything life has given us. The Incan priest, or shaman, Roberto Flores Solis, had opened two similar packages for his ceremony to us five days ago in a eucalyptus grove just above Cusco. It was deeply moving and memorable.

Worth a visit. This market is worth stopping by. It has amazing produce and even a warm food section. Good place to get cheap touristy items like sweaters and mitts aswell. Even if your not looking for anything in particular it is fun to walk around and explore.

Explore, eat and live like a local. If you love exploring and discovering places where locals go to, San Pedro mercado is the place to come to, come early if you can. Here you will find the freshest produce and raw ingredients used to cook all the amazing Peruvian food. You can pick up souvenirs at really great prices and if you're feeling hungry (and your stomach is ready) try some of the dishes that are freshly prepared everyday. A wonderful place to come see and taste the delights that Cusco has to offer.

Visit in the morning or early afternoon. We visited the market late afternoon, and almost all the stalls were already closed. To get the full experience, come earlier in the day or in the early afternoon to avoid disappointment!

Amazing produce. We came to San Pedro Markets with our guide Darwin from Condor Travel and Nemesia our cook for our culinary cooking class. Nemesia, being local took us to all the stalls to buy ingredients we later made into a fantastic lunch at her place. We loved it so much we went back later and after reading another review tilted 'Picarones' we went back in the afternoon to eat the tasty Picarones (doughnuts) for S/-2.5 you get 4 on a plate covered in honey - divine and the lady is so cute. We bought some souvenirs that we thought we reasonably priced. We want to go back for lunch tomorrow!!

Quite an experience!. Amazing market! Biggest in Cusco! There is an aisle for each category : fruits, veggies, meat, cheese, potatoes, corn, spices, weird stuff ( frog logs and donkey noses! yes, donkey noses that smell horrible - could not find anywhere what they use them for ), fresh fruit aisle - had an amazing fresh "cocktail" , tasted and bought the most delicious raisins and crunchy corn here, beautiful flowers, nuts. You can see locals easting here - food smells good - they cook it right in the market! very interesting place - would totally recommend it!!!!

nice place to visit. It opens at 7 am. I arrived early (because I had agenda). It was amazing. The colors, the smells, the variety of natural things of all origins.Maybe the meat part is a little heavy...

So much to see. Would highly recommend a morning wandering through the maze of stalls that sell just about everything you could imagine in fruit, vegetables, meat, fish, meals to eat in, all sorts of health cures and flowers. This is what a market should be like !

Avoid the animal parts aisle if you have a weak stomach.... This is the largest, most beautiful produce and flower market I have ever seen. There are huge aisles of fresh flowers, as well as all types of fruits and vegetables. Chocolates, home herbal remedies, anything you could possibly want is here. (Avoid the souvenir aisles.) We ate the local bread, several fruits ("sweet apple" was best) chocolates and numerous other local foods. We purchased large shelled pecans to take with us. This was one of the highlights of the day. Locals eat here, lined up on stools and benches at tables. Chicken soup looked good.

As local as it can get. If you really want to know how the locals live, eat, or do grocery shopping, this is the place to visit. Grab a fresh (papaya, pineapple, strawberry) juice, enjoy a cheese (queso Andino) sandwich and coffee with fresh cow's milk for breakfast. Or a typical Cusqueno lunch that has a great cost benefit. If you are not hungry, simply buy some quinoa and local spices for your cooking back home. Also a good place to buy local souvenirs. The funny part is that our hotel concierge tried to convince us not to go, since it can be dangerous. Let's be honest, the place is as local as it can get, and it's not the cleanest place around. If you are a hygiene freak (nothing wrong with this), then you can skip this place.

Clear tourist/local divide . San Pedro market is touristy. It caters to tourists, and at any time of the day, at least half the people here will be tourists. Once you step out of the San Pedro market and walk around the surrounding areas, you will see the outside market catering entirely to locals. The divide cannot be stark enough.

interesting morning. Took a food tour of market. Our guide was able to give us history on the women who sew local costumes nad sell through the market, as well as the variety of fare. Obviously a cheap lunch is available for anyone doing a self guided tour, and for the foodies out there this market is more than big enough to find plenty to enjoy.

Picarones. The San Pedro Market is a popular place for the more adventurous eaters to visit and if you are one of the adventurous then give Mama Naty a try, she has a big sign and is usually busy, but you will not be disappointed or go away hungry. If you have room after eating at Mama Naty then go to the next isle over and look for a very sweet little lady making Picarones, out of all of the Picarones I have had in Cusco, hers are definitely the best, and in case you are wondering Picarones are kind of like Peruvian doughnuts but are made from pumpkin and sweet potato.

Great place to visit!. When visiting the Andes, we see lots of archeology sites so it's nice to see a local and authentic market for a change. If you can, do it with a guide that will explain all the different cereals, vegetables and fruits that you can find, their medical use etc... And try to taste a few things (chocolate, quinoa bars, juices), it's really worth it!

Good Variety of Local Articles. I went to this market and it was one of the best I have seen in South America. One can find an assortment of articles from local food items to music CDs (be warned they are all copied and duplicate) to electronic equipment. There's tons of clothing, spices etc. Do ensure you come earlier in the day as that would be the quietest time to visit.

A must do in Cusco. So glad we got a couple of hours in the market just before we left. Large variety or vendors from food and clothing to groceries and juices of all kinds. Shop (and bargain) for souvenirs or enjoy a quick breakfast at one of the stalls, you must spend some time soaking it in as the world in Cusco goes by!

has become quite touristy now.... Unfortunately this market became quite touristy lately and locals are hardly going here anymore for big grocery shopping. On the other hand, everything is cleaner here (still quite messy though), well presented and organised.... And still feels local and authentic... As long as it's not like those famous markets in Madrid or Barcelona I guess it's still worth a visit.
Treat for the eyes. A truely beautiful display of al variety of spices, chees, fruits and vegetables. So clean for a farmers market! ask before you take pictures.

Great local market. If you want to see how the locals shop instead of the straight up tourist shops the this is the place to go. They sell anything and everything and at a fraction of the cost of what you'll pay around the main square. Goes on everyday but expands out bigger on the weekends. Definitely a must see while in cusco!

Great little place for cheap food to cook yourself. Great little place to go shopping! has souvenirs in the front, then all your meat, then fresh fruit and then vegetables. Then right at the far back is where you can eat, cheapest place in town by far, too!... if you don't mind just rice and egg it's 3 Soles!

Don't bother unless you are searching for things to do. I've been to many markets around the world and this is of only average interest. It has fairly common variety of merchandise, and the food did not appear very appetizing to us. The most interesting parts of our time in the market had to do with a company that was holding a celebration and an informal dance in one of the corners. I would only visit this if you have already hit many of the other highlights in Cusco.

You'll find almost everything here. You'll find from fruits and food to everything you need to make an inca's ritual. Very colorful, also you get in touch with locals. Prices are cheap than restaurants. In you're short in money should eat there everyday.
Fascinating…its where all the locals are.... Diverse, fun, really get to see the nice people…great eats…it was the most authentic part of Cusco…great interaction with the people

Try the Smoothies. Cool little market off the main historical district. They have everything under the sun - meat, vegetables, handicrafts, restaurants. There is a whole row of vendors selling fresh fruit smoothies. A definite must.

Eat here every day. San Pedro Central market is a market close to San Pedro church. On weekend and holidays, the market expands many blocks with people selling all sort of things on the streets. Fruits, vegetables, meats, seafood, housewares, etc... We eat at the market without any problem and we are from USA. Local cuisines are organized along specialties sections in the market. We eat mostly in the soup section. This market is a good place to have good, local foods.

Local market that caters to locals.. We went there every day for lunch and dinner. We are a family of 4 from the US. Have no problem at all handling foods or drinks. Good place to buy fruits and vegetables. That market expands to several blocks during weekends and holidays.

Quite an experience. A visit to Cusco would not be complete without visiting the market. It is about a 10 minute walk from the Main Square. There were tourists browsing around, but by far the clientele were locals. This is where they shop. You will see whole butchered hogs ready for the pit or parts thereof. Many whole chickens ready to cook. Different stalls had piles of fresh vegetables and fruit, as well as many packaged goods. We found a bag of chia for $2 that one in our party said would go for $20 in the US. Along with general grocery items, there were a few souvenir type shops. There also is an extensive food court area where one can buy and eat almost whatever you want. The visit to the market was quite an experience.

Colorful market. We visited this market hoping to catch lunch at one of the pop up restaurants we had read about. However we were not so sure about the cleanliness of the food and so we decided not to risk eating there. We did buy some cheese and bread and had a little picnic on the Plaza just outside the market. We had fruit smoothies in the market and the ladies who make them were super sweet! Lots to look at in the market-- so colorful and a great glimpse into local culture.

Experience the local way of life. This place gives you an insight to the way people eat and live in Cusco. The variety of foods and the preparation of foods are interesting to watch. If you are a foodie you will want to go here to view the exchanges and liveliness of the market.

GENUINE PERUVIAN MARKET. The San Pedro Market in Cusco is frequented by locals and tourists alike. Poultry and meat are butchered and displayed without refrigeration, but so fresh that the market is without offensive oder. Jewelry and other gifts surround the periphery and are reasonably priced even before bargaining. A worthwhile destination while touring Cusco.

Big market. Similar other markets around the world, Here the people from cuzco buy the species, fruits,etc. You can see the traditional market at Peru. Take care outside at night. Is little far from the Place ( around 10 blocks )

The real Cusco. Step outside of the Centro Historico and go to the Mercado de San Pedro. No expensive restaurants right here although there are some nice ones nearby. There is of course a church and there is a nice arched gate before you enter here. There are street vendors selling all types of food and merchandise for a much cheaper price. There is quite a variety. The street food is better than most restaurants but buy it freshly made. It will cost a dollar or two or maybe three if your hungry. It's very crowded here especially outside the market which I prefer. Cheaper prices.

A Fascinating Place. While planning our Peruvian vacation our group decided to add a cooking class to our agenda. As part of that event our chef took us through the San Pedro market to demonstrate how the community acquires products for their local kitchens. The market covers a very large area, under roof but still in open air. The market is divided into a number of well marked areas including Fruits, Vegetables, Juices, Textiles, Spices, etc. The juices area was unique as those vendors were very vocally active in getting our attention. There are also plenty of souvenirs available in the market as well as a "restaurant" where you can sit down and enjoy lunch in the market. The meat department was amazing not only for the quantity and variety of meats but also because there was large quantities of meat on display without the aid of refrigeration. Although not the exclusive means of transport, many of the vendors use wheelbarrows to supply the market. Quite a colorful sight! We had previously noticed that there were a disproportionate number of wheelbarrows for sale in local storefronts. We had found one of the answers!

Full of Options. I loved these markets. Extremely well segmented and signed, with some amazingly delicious and cheap set menu options. Theres a fresh juice bar section, textiles and ware's to purchase for super affordable prices.

Outstanding Cultural Experience. San Pedro was fun, cheap, and tasty. It's the central (black) market that rumors say the locals patronize. At San Pedro one can find anything: souvenirs, dog food, fresh fruit, or meals. The prices for souvenirs are the best in town, pre-bartering. The foods are insanely cheap and give you a taste of real Peruvian food. And, if you're from a westernized country, the meats section is a must.Recommend setting aside 1-2 hours for a complete visit to San Pedro.

Veryyyy Interesting! Must see.. This is a must see in Cusco. We loved walking through the market and blending like a local. Try the juice. Buy from the locals. I wasn't brave enough to try the food. Check out the photo below. Great experience.

mix with the locals. Like one of the recent reviewers, I always make it a priority to visit local food markets when travelling as it gives a real taste of the country, and this one is no exception. A short couple of blocks from the plaza it is an easy way to fill an hour or two. I heard about the pickpockets and even though it was quite busy I felt safe and escaped 'untouched'. Lots of photo opportunities, but be aware that some of the vendors may not want to be photographed just as some may not want to answer your questions about their products - I usually find they are in the minority and this was no different in Cusco - simply hold your camera up for them to see and you will get a reaction that is easy to understand

Authenic Puruivan Local Market. This is must when in Cusco. One of my favorite places to go during my travels is the local market – it’s really the only way to see the real culture, food, traditions and every day local life. I could have spent hours and hours walking around here. For some, it may be too much – for me - it’s why I travel, as I enjoy getting out of my comfort zone, and learning about other cultures. We went on Saturday, and then again on a weekday - both days were busy. There is an array of colors, foods, grains, clothes, fruit juices, prepared foods, bread – anything needed for daily life. Make sure you walk inside the building where you will find food stalls, fish, meat, fresh juices, etc. The “animal parts” section was quite the experience. Some areas are difficult to swallow (or smell), but who are we to judge? Make sure to respect the locals, and be aware when taking pictures - most locals don’t want their pictures taken, so try to be discreet. Also, as in any area with crowds, watch you pockets and bags, as this would be an easy place for pickpockets, although we had no issues. Outside the “market” area you can walk for blocks & blocks and discover more local shopping areas. We enjoyed this area, but again be safe – we had a police officer stop us, reminding us to be aware of pickpockets. Although I would have loved to tried the food, we didn’t, as I didn’t want to take the chance of getting my pristine Western stomach sick. Per Western standards, the market food is unsanitary and is obviously not regulated as you see dirty hands touching food everywhere, not to mention the flies landing on the food. We had a friend who ate at this market and had no problems – just eat at your own risk

great - just go but dont be afraid of engaging with folks - be considerate about taking photos.. Really happy to have visited on a number of occasions to take a juice and relax - yes chill with the stall holders and browse for my cooking class and for random supplies for trekking. Don't approach the lady skinning frogs legs - but in general remember these are people at work doing trade and business - part of that - like in your home country - thust a camera in their faces without common courtesy of considering.

Great Food at great prices. To really see how the locals live and eat, visit the market to see all sorts of animal, produce and lots of meals to choose from. The food stall are organized by type - sandwiches in one row, rice platters, soups vendors etc.

Watch your wallet. My rating comes with a big caveat - beware of pickpockets. You think you'll see them coming but you won't. Other than that, this is an authentic, exhilarating Peruvian experience....roast guinea pigs on skewers, etc. Just be ultra careful.

Very large, and has everything you need!. If you're looking to buy any fresh food or even some souvenirs, this is the place to do it. Be warned that the meat section has foods that are atypical for Westerners and may freak you out a little bit, but it's a great place to walk through. Watch out for sanitation, though - it is quite sketchy in most places, as the people will handle the food and your money with gloves on and don't change out their gloves, so it's basically like they're not wearing gloves. If you go to the fruit smoothie section, you can get 3 cups of the smoothie for the price, which turns out to be a great deal!

This Market has it all. Full of colour, character and an excellent place to grab some local food with the locals. It's a busy place with lots of sights, sounds and smells to be absorbed. Definitely worth a visit.

Recommendable!. Visit San Pedro Mercado if you want to see and experience cusquenias life. The market is a huge space they sell fresh food, fruits, different kind of juices, cheap handycraft and more.This was probably the most local place you can visit in Cusco.

Wow!. This is a market to beat all markets! It is huge, and sells everything from fresh chicken soup to fruit smoothies to dog chow. You want it? It's here. My 5 travel companions and I went to this market on several occasions. We are all artists and photographers, and the lure of the market was insatiable. Fresh Peruvian cheeses, hot fresh baked sweet breads, nuts, chicken soup, everything but the kitchen sink smoothies from fresh fruits. Wow! Also incomparable for people watching. You may even see head bones from butchered alpacas on counter tops. One morning we saw a pig being delivered, before we left we saw the pig - head and feet removed, laying on a counter ready for butchering to spec. It is not pretty, but a reminder that in many countries meat is not delivered in pretty styrofoam packages in shrinkwrap. Lot's of old grannies sit on the concrete floor selling everything from quinoa to mushrooms. Just a friendly word...this is the reality of these folks, so be considerate with cameras.

Amazing cultura and very good special juice.. I recommend everyone to see this market where locals actually shop and eat. There is a huge food court with home made meals. Its not recommended to eat for tourists because of sanitary conditions. However we tried and amazing special freshly squeezed juice with dark beer, canned milk and lots of different fruits and vegetables. It became the most delicious smoothie I ever had. We shared this huge drink with our guide.

A must see. This was an awesome market! You have to go! My daughter purchased a selfie stick on the plaza and it didn't fit her phone but she was able to trade it for an awesome bag here with no problem. You have to go just to see the sites even if you don't plan on purchasing anything.

Comprehensive. I was impressed with the market. It was big. There was a large variety of things sold, from textiles, jewelry, to fresh produce, food and coffee. One could get lunch (local Peruvian) there if inclined. The merchants weren't pushy. We bought some local coffee and chocolate. It was better than the Pissac market. I'd recommend all visitors taking a gander.

Price is right. As others have stated, this is a market for the people, as well as visitors. Everything from cows noses and jaws to coca leaves, maca, chia, fresh fruits and corn, chocolate, dresses for your daughters and Peruvian handicrafts! Prices here are half of what they were in the "artisanal" market, and we didn't bother to do any negotiations as the prices were already pretty low and certainly reasonable.
