Lots of stalls at the back to sit and eat, either chicken soup or rice dishes, average cost was 5 soles, pretty cheap eats! There are lots of stalls outside the market too, we spent about an hour wandering the streets there, streets are none too clean, but the market was.

Something for everyone. San Pedro was far better than the supposed "artisan market" up the street. It's more authentic, less tourist-trappy. You can buy all the usual hats and accessories, as well as view the food.....So many kinds of potatoes! Interesting place to wander through.

Huge variety of local produce, goods and food stalls. We loved wandering through each aisle to see the wide variety of produce and goods for sale. The flower area smelled amazing and the fruits looked delicious! We had juice at one of the juice bars and chatted with the nice girls serving there. Our favorite was the pineapple orange juice but the mango, orange and passion fruit juice was also very good. It's a great spot to see many local people and get a small glimpse of the culture. You only need about 30 minutes to an hour to see everything but could spend much longer enjoying food from the various stalls. These seemed very popular with the locals.

A great atmosphere. This is definitely one to visit in Cusco. It's a fabulous mix of all sorts of food and other products with places to eat simple food and to drink a huge variety of fresh juices. It is probably the most colourful place in an already colourful Cusco.

A Feast for the senses. I almost missed this fabulous market so make sure you don't. Inside you will find fresh fish, fruits, vegetables, meats, grains, cheeses, flowers, medicinal herbs and the usual assortment of local handmade clothing. Reasonable hot meals are served at the back of this mercado. Juice bars abound where you have a choice of local fruits made into delicious smoothies for less than 10 soles. This is an opportunity to eat local for less.

A Must-See in Cusco!. Lots of tourists in Cusco on their way to Machu Picchu. A rare place not far from tourist sites where you can mix with the local population. The sites, sounds, and smells are incredible. The soups served in the mercado are also quite exceptional and priced for locals, not tourists. The locals we met were quite friendly and we loved the rare chance to converse with Peruvians not in the tourism industry.

Don't miss this great local market. A food market is always a great place to begin to understand the food culture of a place that you are visiting.This bustling market, often missed from tour guide itineraries, shows a fascinating mix of ingredients and cooked foods, alongside clothing and other manufactured items.Added to this, the colourful and engaging images of local people, just getting on with their lives, makes this a place not to be missed.You can of course also eat there with them too and enjoy authentic and inexpensive local foods.

The True Wealth of the Incas. San Pedro is the main local market of the locals, the descendants of the Incas, and here you can see fabulous displays of the source of the wealth of their imperial ancestors. No, not rooms full of gold; that gold was the result of their wealth, nor the source. The source was agriculture. It's been estimated that the farmers of the Inca's empire most of the foods that are eaten in the world today: no mean feat given that most of the empire was either frigid mountain or scorching desert. But the Andeans gave the Irish their potatoes, the Italians their tomatoes, the Central Europeans their Hungarian paprika and the Southeast Asians their Thai peppers as well as the quinine in the gin and tonics that were indispensable in malarial lands. Not to mention peanuts and cashews, squash and sweet potatoes, papayas and strawberries. Where would the Hawaiians be without pineapples? Where would the Belgians be without chocolate? Or Bugs Bunny without carrots? Luckily for world cuisine, much of this cornucopia has spread to the ends of the earth. But not all of it. Some of the best stuff is still largely unknown. But it's known in the San Pedro Market, and bought and sold every day. Here you can see 20 different varieties of corn in every color in the rainbow (as well as white, black, and grey, which were inadvertently left out of the rainbow), arranged as artistically as the goods at a Hanoi flower mart (see picture). There you can find long, long rows of potatoes, forty different varieties, purple, green, lemon with red spots, others long and thin like delicate fingers, with tiger stripes of black on orange (see photo). Back toward the east side of the market, one section is devoted entirely to hierbes medicinales: what ails you, neighbor? Gastritis, ulcers, prostate, diabetes? We've got you covered, whatever it is, and no, you don't need a prescription! (See photo) Recalling that these were the folks who'd given the medical world quinine, ipecac and the coca leaf, I wanted to ask what they had for altitude sickness, but my Spanish failed me. There are of course lots of other things at San Pedro, and other reviewers have discussed the fruit juice stands, the innards row, the poultry, the sausage vendors. But markets on other continents have such things. I was drawn to the items unique to the Andes. Extending that to coastal Peru, San Pedro has a good, cheap and popular cevicheria as well, in the northeast part of the market, which is well worth a stop (see photo).

Must see!. Brilliant place to get cheap everything! When visiting Cuzco you must spend 20-30 mins meandering through the market here where they sell dream catchers, multi fruit smoothies, a selection of glorious cheeses and nuts to grilled whole Guinea pig!The different smells of the market mixed with browsing without any hassle make this a memory not to forget!

Shop With The Locals. Worth a visit to wander amongst the locals and tourists alike where you can buy the obligatory alpaca handicrafts, pan-flutes, key rings etc but also a dizzying array of local produce. Rows of juice bars, fresh fruits and vegetables, meats, fish, and homewares all jostle for space and customers alongside clothes, handicrafts, dressmakers and jewellers. The sights and smells, particularly those of the butchers and fishmongers, add to the colour and atmosphere. Well worth a visit just to wander and mix it with the locals whilst maybe picking up a bargain or two.

Go for cheap eats. We met some gals who were backpacking and had been eating at San Pedro Market almost exclusively. We went to check it out and it's no wonder these gals on a budget were here every day. The food was great and insanely inexpensive. It's great to walk around the various produce sections but in the back are stalls you can eat at. Most are serving variations on the same stuff so just look for the happiest looking lady behind the counter or busiest seating area. There is also a whole row of vendors doing fresh fruit juices. Great stop-- especially on a budget.

Tasty and fresh food that's very reasonable . It's where the locals eat and hang out. Loved the Mercado and used to visit this place everyday. From the fresh juices to avocado sandwich for breakfast, ceviche for lunch and saltado for dinner- I enjoyed it all. Lots of food carts and stalls with different local food are set up outside the Mercado in the evening. Good place to pick up dry fruits and souvenirs too. I would highly recommend visiting the Mercado while in Cusco.

Super market - prepare to haggle. The market is kind of divided in two. First there's the set menu food hall and juice bar which is really authentic, great value and absolutely buzzing with local Quechua folk. Don't miss this, unless your stomach's playing up :SOn the other hand the fresh food and definitely the textiles markets are very set up for tourists. There's a good range and you can negotiate, but you might need a few tricks to get a bargain.Whatever price you go for, the stall owners generally act offended! So persevere. The best tactic we found was to wait for a local to shop in the stall you wanted, so you could hear the 'real' price of things and refer to that in your bartering.Overall, a great fun place to be - don't miss it.For more Cuzco travel tips, check out our blog!https://ednaventures.wordpress.com/2014/12/09/cuzco-a-beautiful-countdown/

Don't miss this local market!. An aisle for EVERYTHING! Meats, vegetables, fruits, breads, flowers, souveniers - it's all right here and everything has its' own aisle! We had been told the history of the bulls adorning Peruvian homes and wanted to bring a pair home with us. We found them here! Our guide purchased and shared with us some traditional Peruvian bread that was the best bread I have ever eaten - anywhere! I could have wandered through this market for hours. There is also an entire aisle devoted to serving lunch so stop for a bite to eat. More into smoothies? There is an aisle devoted to making those creations as well. Unbelievable market. Don't miss a visit!

A wonderful local market. A large covered market area where locals shop. Here you can find all kinds of fresh and cooked foods, treats, fruits, vegies, and souvenirs at cheap prices. Like many local markets this is a non-touristy site that any tourist should take the time to visit.

Where the locals shop. This is the main local market in town and features staples of daily Peruvian life, a food court in addition to more touristy items for gringos. It's an easy walk from Plaza San Francisco and well worth checking out.

Great market for food and souvenirs. This is a great multi-purpose market with lots of stalls devoted to fresh juice and cheese and you can buy chocolate (cooking and artesian). Souvenirs are 40 per cent of the price we were quoted at the Machu Picchu craft market for the identical product. We brought chocolate as gifts as well and they were cheaper than in the supermarkets across from the market. Thankfully there aren't many fresh meat stalls so the market doesn't smell rancid.

Largest market! Great shopping.. This market is huge! Definitely allow time here to explore the local artisans, great flowers, food and more. As a vegetarian, I skipped walking up and down the meat aisles...there was plenty to see from afar. I recommend planning to eat lunch here - there are plenty of stands serving soup and other food to eat. Many vendors do not speak English, so be ready to ask a few questions in Spanish.

Must see! . The San Pedro market is cusco is the best one that I have visited among cusco and Lima. We visited this place as park of the cooking class and then come back later again by ourselves. It is interesting to see all the various products here, like the collection of different type of corns across Peru! I bought some coco candy here as souvenir which is cheaper than the shops near plaza de armes. (please notice that it is illegal to bring coco leaves back to your home country). There are many many small stalls that sell juice and food. The caldo de pollo here is excellent!! Big bowl is s/10 while small bowl bowl is s/5 !

Fun if you have time. I wouldn't go out of my way to go here, but if you have some time to spare, it's worth it. Close to many of the other Cusco attractions, and they sell a great variety of stuff. A good selection of food, as well as tourist items.

Try not to eat here!. The San Pedro market is a nice place to go and buy seeds, fruits, plants souvenirs even candy and such but please refrain yourself from eating there. You can see a bunch of local people eating there but the sanitary conditions of the market are really poor. Even our tour guide told us that he would not recommend us eating there. I did try the "Choclo" which is a type of corn that people eat over there with cheese. Pretty good.

Best Market of the Trip. The San Pedro Market was hands down the best Market we went to and we did go to a bunch. Our guide took us here our 1st day in Cusco for the juice and it was delish. The place is so cool and the locals are friendly. It is a must see in Cusco. My husband even tried the Chicha - purple corn beer. The juice is so fresh and made from anything you can imagine. The shopping is pretty decent too for alpaca items.

Great place to get lost. Our Airbnb apartment is just a few blocks from the San Pedro market, and we are so happy to have ended up here, both to be outside of the direct Plaza de Armas tourism and, more importantly, to be near this market.We have been several times on our trip, and it is really the perfect place to stock up on anything. Despite the chaos that first presents itself, this market is actually very organized. It is roughly divided into local crafts, food supplies for sale (an aisle each for cheese, bread, various meats, etc.) and fresh food for purchase. Once we got the hang of it it became very useful for supplies.Having now traveled a bit around Cusco, the prices are not heavily marked up here; in fact, they were often lower (and more up for negotiation) than in several other places. We bought, in no particular order, sweaters, hats, socks, bananas, a bucket of fresh local fruit, a ham sandwich, tamales, and a miniature alpaca. They even have supplies like batteries, tea, etc.This is like having a giant grocery store where everything is fresh and local and you have lots of variety. Definitely one of the highlights of the trip.

Great place to spend an hour or two. The San Pedro market is a great place to spend an hour or two. With stalls full of fruit, flowers, grains, potatoes, meats, fish, it's a colourful and sometimes pungent place to visit.Not to mention the stalls of clothes and fabrics around the outside, and the many stalls selling ready to eat food.Note - both our Inca Trail guide and a woman I bought coffee from told me to be careful with valuables. The coffee vendor specifically told me to put my wallet in my front pocket and keep my hand on it. So, more than other places in downtown Cusco, pickpocketing may be an issue here. So just be careful

Worth a visit!. I visited San Pedro as part of a cooking class, and am happy I did. It was interesting to see all the produce options, fresh flowers and cheeses, etc. there were a few spots that were rough in terms of meat displays and live animals (frogs), but that goes with the territory.
amazing. located very close to the city center, this colourful and very crowded market is a must when you visit cuzco. just pay attention at the pickpockets around, they r very skillfull

Great local market. This was probably one of the best markets we've ever been too. Spacious. clean and a huge variety of things to buy, all laid out in a logical and easy way to follow. Large food court with some of the best value food I've seen. Highly recommend a visit.

Fun local market. This isn't your usual shopping as it is a local market that sells a combination of everything from food stuff like meat, vegetables to clothes and art & craft items. It's got a wet market kind of setting where I think the locals actually go.I went there to get my stash of Palo Santo wood and traditional floral water to bring home and it was fun looking at the local market. I don't think it's a typical touristy kind of place and that's precisely why I like it. You might still want to bargain a bit as some of them know you're a tourist and will quote you higher prices but generally, the prices for the art & craft stuff is comparable to the ones outside and it isn't a hell lot cheaper. It's nice to just check it out anyway.

Very local . This is really where you need to go to experience the local culture. I have been to many street markets in the world and this one is very unique as they have everything separated. One row of cheese. One row of breads. Then one area with sweet food and one with soups. We decided to have the potato soup with cilantro and no meat to be safe. And it was the best soup of our trip. Don't be scared just try it.

Best Local Market in Peru. This market has everything. We entered through the food department which is mainly patronized by the locals. Everything you can imagine and then some. Does not smell all that good (the meat section) but you will see meat that you could not identify. Very interesting. The craft section, mainly for tourists was very large. We noticed that the merchants were not especially agressive, but we were able to bargain with them. We found items that we did not see anywhere else in Peru. We spent only about an hour in the market as part of a city tour, but it would be easy to spend an entire day. We were looking for black Quinuoa in a sealed package so we could take it home. It took awhile but we found it and had no problems with customs.

Authentic food market. A wonderful, local, authentic food market. It seems to be the place were the locals do their grocery shopping. There is also a food court that serves local dishes for cheap. Take a few minutes for a walk through - it's just a few minutes walk from Plaza de Armas.

A sight to see. It smells, it's crowded, and vendors are literally chasing you down to buy their product. But absolutely worth a visit. You can get lost in all the items there are to buy, eat and drink. Some of the strangest stuff I've ever seen, too. Spend some time people watching - it was a great afternoon.

Wet, dirty, but go anyway!. Went to San Pedro as part of a guided tour in Cusco. Enjoyed the visit and was fun to see what's sold there. Horrors - go visit the meat section and have a look! ;-) We bought local chocolates as souvenirs to bring home. Memorable - must go. It is only a short walk from the main square.

Fantastic wet market, great souvenirs, fresh fruit juice stands. San Pedro markets is not far from the main square about 10 minutes stroll. It has an excellent wet market with some very exotic foods. Not for the faint hearted...takes eating snout to tail very literally. There were affordable souvenirs to be bought and the best tasting fresh fruit juices. Well worth the visit.

Local market of food and places to eat. This market was really nice to watch - its mainly food but we arrived at lunch time and enjoyed seeing the locals all sit around big tables and had the traditional soup. There is not too much to buy that you cant find in other places around Cusco, but It was a nice trip to the market and the area.

A glimpse into local life. We visited this market as part of the Cusco tour with G Adventures. It is a giant complex packed with stalls selling all kinds of goods you can imagine. It has such a local favour and it's eye opening to see the different produce and customs of the locals. The market is organized by sections: there are vegetables and fruits (hundreds of potato varieties and the most exotic fruits from the amazon); meat stalls (all kinds of animals and cuts); dried goods; flowers; handicrafts; food. Perhaps the most interesting is what our tour guide coined the "ritual and 'witchcraft' section". These stalls are filled with goods and products that are used by locals for all of their history. There are things used for rituals and praying, artifacts and charms for luck and blessings, herbal remedies for sickness, and so on. It was a very interesting stroll, just be careful of your goods and wallets (our guide made sure to remind us before we head in and we all came out safe and sound).

Definitely worthwhile if you like food markets. This had what you'd expect from a local food market, allowing you to really understand what people in the city eat. In addition to many food stalls, there's a large section of stalls with prepared food to eat for really authentic yet really cheap meals (eg we had a rice dish that was most of both my and my wife's lunch for the equivalent of $1.20 USD).The only part I didn't like was that all food stalls of one kind where adjacent to one another and appeared to be required to use the same format (even signs). While this certainly helped to section things off - they even had overhead signs like I'm a grocery store - I felt like it took away from the creativity and surprise, and led to this strange situation where if you're looking down an aisle, all the vendors would waive to you to tell you to come to theirs even though each stall was basically identical.

Great experience!. A true local covered market selling everything, and I mean everything. Huge place. Fruit and vegetables to make your mouth water, eating, clothing, housewares, everything. A real cultural experience.

Great place for buying food. This place is a great option for buying unexpensive food in Cusco.You can find fruits, bread and lots of nuts, olives...They also prepare meals and juices there, but that I didn´t tried.You can also find lots of handcrafts and other stuffs too...

Nice little market with great cheap food. They have everything at this market, and its really nice to walk around to have a look. The food at the market, or well, ive only tried the juices and soups, but its so good and so cheap! You get a good portion of soup for 2,50 soles. Look for the quinoa drink, its only 1 soles and definitely worth trying!

Fantastic . The short story is that this is a fantastic local market with incredible, cheap food, a ton of different spices, medicines and so on and also great options for buying cheap clothes and other souvenirs/gifts. I ate here every day and never once felt unsafe or poorly treated (although being a gringo one must really be fine with a little bit of eye rolling and attitude).

Most interesting food market I have ever visited. Many tour books suggest going to local open markets to get the 'flavor' of a place [flavor in two ways]. The market in Barcelona was neat, but this place beats all others I have been to – by a head. Donkey head that is – which you can buy whole here, or just the snout. Or get a whole cattle head. Of course there are whole pigs. Live frogs. The list goes on and on. And not a refrigerator in sight. Not just meat - we bought nuts, dried fruit, bread, fruit – and ate it most of it immediately. We also went back to the cooked food [lunch] area and had a pecado frito placa. A piece of fried fish [bone in], lentils, rice and beans to cover the plate [placa] for 3.50 soles – about a buck and a quarter!
Interesting place. It's an experience. One can find (and buy) there anything local, from out-of-season lucuma to San Pedro and coca leaves, of course

A shopping experience. Going here is a feast for the senses! I wish we had visited on our other free days. Unfortunately, we had only four hours to browse before we headed to the airport. They sell everything--it's like a flea market, a farmer's market, a street food fair and an artisan market all mashed into one busy place. Lots of great photo opportunities too and a great way to immerse yourself in local culture. FYI, keep your valuables and money close to you when wandering. I had a few friendly stall owners warn me when I was fumbling for money in my pockets like an idiot.When I come back to Cuzco, I will do most of my shopping here.
A slice of local life. If you have a half hour - well worth a look.All sorts of foods and goods. Many items can be bargained.

Good place to pick up souveniers. We did almost all our shopping there but fruit smoothie that my husband had made and bought there made him very sick. I did not have any because I am always wary of local water that is not bottled. Bargaining is acceptable here especially if you buy more than one item.

A feast for the eyes- but not for the feint of heart. Be prepared to be barraged by sights smells colors and sounds. See weavers stalls, toys, horses heads, pigs heads, meats of all sorts (don't worry- they cover them with sheets overnight) peppers fruits vegetables frogs legs cauldrons of steaming soups. Bring your camera for spy shots of the people.

Best Value. This is where I bought most of my food. I would often eat here as well. There is no where else in the world where you could get a home cooked meal for S./3.50 ~ $.1.20. This meal comes with a large bowl of soup and a class of Manzanilla or mint tea.It is a place you must see.

Mercado Central de San Pedro (San Pedro Central Market). If it is locally grown, it can be found at the San Pedro Market. Here you’ll find fresh produce, meats of numerous varieties, homemade cheeses, grains and even kitchenware, clothes and home decorations. The market is divided up much like a grocery or department store, with booths selling similar items on the same aisle (or multiple aisles).Definitely check out some for the items available. Need a whole hog or a side of beef, just a few llama steaks or even a guinea pig for dinner? It is all available. There is also a food court serving local dishes prepared on site, complete with roving musicians. Of course there is a tourist section selling souvenirs. In this section, beware of the ‘alpaca’ scarves and other items sold here. The prices reflect authenticity.If you have a little free time while in Cusco, you should visit San Pedro Market. If you only walk through or spend a greater amount of time exploring each aisle, visit the market and absorb the local culture and a part of the daily way of life in the Andes. It is east of the train station and just a few blocks west of the historic district.

Working market filled with local produce, a find for foodies.. This market is bustling and filled with people selling everything from fresh produce to grocery staples. There are a few handi-craft stalls, but only a few.This market is great for seeing truly local foods. Cheeses, breads, grains, spices, dried seaweeds, and more. There is a section devoted to animal parts, so if you are squeamish to such things, you may want to avoid the meat area.There were all sorts of foods that were unfamiliar: little freeze dried potatoes, partially dried fish eggs, and various roots and tubers.In the center of the market are vendors making fresh fruit juices and other things to eat at the market. We stopped for a bowl of chicken soup, it was simple and very tasty. If you are adventurous, sitting and having a bowl of soup is truly a local eating experience.
Really cheap!. You can find really cheap crafts than downtown! Its open from 6:00am til 8:00pm and you can get there walking from the plaza.

Clean and Interesting. We were brought here for the "Behind the Scenes, Cusco" and tasted the Chuta Bread and a different "pipino" cucumber fruit!We were introduced to a lady who is like a human food processor. She cuts potato like a machine in a precise julienne and also diced in perfect pieces! Amazing!

Top tips for visiting Mercado Central de San Pedro, Cusco Peru. - Not your usual fancy French or Italian market- Dirty water and food waster everywhere, that's what makes it so authentic.- This is where all the locals shop for their daily groceries- Things are so much cheaper in the market- A bag of 200g - 500g quinoa literally cost 5 soles. A 50 gram chia seed cost 2 soles.- Don't be afraid to join in the locals and have a bowl of famous chicken noodle soup for 5 soles (see picture). It is so flavoursome!- Along the way to the San Perdo market, you will see tons of cerviche stall. They are only 2 soles for a small tiny plate sold at the street stall. I strongly encourage and recommend you to try it. I had 3 plates in a row, guarantee no food poisoning. It is truly a brand new culinary experience for the most famous dish in Peru.- Didn't really see a lot of gringos hanging out in the food markets here. Maybe they were worried of being mugged or having food poisoning. - The market also sells touristy souvenirs but super overpriced.- Wear a good pair of covered shoes because you do not want to wet your feet with dirty water.- Lots of quail eggs sellers, steamed boiled potato sellers and fruit/vege sellers.- Very difficult to find a toilet around here.If you think my reviews have been helpful to you, please click 'Yes' for 'Was this review helpful?'

Great cultural experience, yes the market.. You have many traditional souvenirs and textiles to pick from. There is also the food market. Exotic fruits, vegetable, cheese, meats, breads, chocolates, its all there and then some...You can also get a great bowl of freshly made chicken noodle soup for 5 sole, cheap and delicious. Great fun for all!
A 'must see' in Cusco!. If you want to buy souvenirs and yet experience the best from the local culture, this is the place to go.

Full of Surprises. This is a fun little market to visit! It was designed by Eiffel and gets a lot of popularity points for that! Definitely worth a walkthrough! Keep your eyes peeled because you will be sure to see some interesting things!

Excellent place to taste local culture. I went to Mercado Central in Cusco in a rainy Sunday. Not many people were out that day but was perfect to take pictures and taste the local culture. You can find local handcrafts in this market. I got me an alpaca with cap and scarf at an incredible low price! outside the market, there were public protests about public transportation cost and I heard they would go on strike the next day. Overall, a great experience!

Get the local experience. If you really want to know what the locals do and go, San Pedro Market is the place to be. Not to mention it's the cheapest place for lunch. We spent 5 soles (a little less than $2) each for a big bowl of chicken soup. And we went to the pricey chicken soup aisle.Rows and rows of produce (fruits, vegetables, raw meat, fish) and other products. We spent several hours wandering up and down the aisles marveling over what you would buy there.

Local experience. My friends and I loved San Pedro market. We thoroughly enjoyed bargaining for souvenirs here and finishing off the experience with a bowl of chicken soup. The chicken soup was one of the best meals we had in cusco (cheap, tasty, authentic). I only wish I could go here again.

Experience the Cusqueno daily live. Come to visit San Pedro Mercado if you want to see and experience the locals' daily life. The market is an enormous space that houses over a hundred fresh food stores and tens of eateries serving delicious local cuisine.
Great atmosphere. Good food. (Very) cheap eats. Wonderful locals.
This was probably the most local place you can visit in Cusco.
everything at once. If you want to see what the locals eat, go to the mercado. Here you can find all sorts of fruit, veggies and meat (litteraly everything!). you can also buy souvenirs.

So Unique. What a total culture experience! Loved this place. Nothing makes you feel like you are in a totally different culture than the San Pedro Market. So many colors, flavors, smells, things to wonder at. Not for everyone, but if you really want to experience something totally different. This is the place. Needless to say, great prices on everything.

Lots of unique things to see!. San Pedro Market is a 5-10 min walk from the Plaza de Armas. While there are handicrafts sold in one area, go to see the diverse food. See how the locals shop. Room temperature meat/seafood waiting to be bought-smells a bit...mounds of fruit, sacks full of grain, cheese, unique breads. This is definitely worth walking through. It can be done in 30-45 minutes. There are food stalls where you can sit and order. There are interesting things to see just outside the market, too-people selling food from their wheelbarrows, carts with small birds laying eggs on the bottom with a woman cooking them and selling boiled eggs on top. Great place for photos.

Unique!. Very cool place. The meat market was astounding- cattle heads, brains, entire pigs, etc. I highly recommend the juice section. Cheap, healthy, friendly, and great tasting! You can also get very cheap meals in the restaurant section if you're brave enough to trust what they're serving.

Don't miss!!. This market is amazing. So many colors, people, variety, smells (good and bad). It's worth going to look around even if you don't buy anything. I recommend going to the food stalls in the morning and getting a fried cheese and avocado sandwich with some chocolate con leche. Amazing and super cheap. Look out for donkey snouts.

Where the locals go. For a town sustained by tourism it is nice to duck into the Mercado Central to escape the touts and higher prices. A nicely sectioned covered market, this is where you can pick up some local produce or that little something to take back home. Some decent food options are also found here. Just a short walk from the main square.

Great local market. Mercado Central is a great place to get a sense of the breadth and diversity of produce available in Peru. The variety of vegetables and fruit is incredible and there are stalls to get excellent fruit juices. The stalls include some typical breakfast and Chufa dining experiences and the market is filled with folks doing their regular daily shopping. We thoroughly enjoyed this mercado because, unlike some others, this felt much less touristy. We bought several incredibly delicious fruits to try and also had some wonderful conversations with vendors in the market.

Oldest Market in Cusco & Very Fun!. I love visiting local markets wherever I go so of course had to take a trip to San Pedro. The stalls are always filled with the things the locals need to buy, as opposed to the typical tourist markets. The wet section- the fish market... the meats... the produce... and all the dry goods are always a trip to check out.This market spills outside the covered marketplace to the surrounding streets, and they are really fun to walk thru as well. I had one of my most memorable meals of this trip from a street vendor, who was deep frying chunks of meat laid over vegetables. Questionable sanitation? Undoubtedly. Delicious? Oh yeah!

Bit of a let down. Went with high hopes of lots of god stuff to buy but just usual tourist stuff. Smell and sights of food stalls was awful especially for a vegetarian. Only there half an hour. Better markets in Cusco
a must. Great place to see and understand life in The Andes. Check the meat market and definitely stop by for breakfast at any of the jugos stands.

Highland soup and 'real' Cusco. My husband and I visited the market on our second day in Cisco. It is fun, lively and attractive - anything and everything piled high for sale. And it feels as if you are seeing a 'real' bit of Cisco. It isn't as overwhelming as the markets in more developing countries and is a better experience for it. We got very little hassle from anyone - nothing more than a friendly "senor/a" (said once or twice per stall holder, with a smile).We had read that Highland Soup is good for the altitude headache so chose a stall with lots of customers. It was actually one that was in the main market area rather than the main eating area but that wasn't really a conscious choice (the one with lime green cushions on the benches). We paid 10 neuvo sol for 2 huge bowels of soup (chicken, veg and pasta) and it was wonderful. And the headaches went for an hour or so! Highly recommended!

Come here for lunch. It’s only a short walk from Plaza de Aramas in the Historical District, and it’s where you’ll get some great photo ops (see my pictures). You’ll find many items for sale here at local prices. My partner bought wool fabric for 5 soles per metre and found a tailor here to sew up a coat for seven soles.There are several juice bars in another section where you can get fresh fruit juice, and a food court where you can eat chicken and vegetable soup, ranging from 4 soles to 10 soles for a big plate (I’ve eaten here several times without getting sick).If you’re into drugs you can find San Pedro, Mesculin, Maca and Harina de Coca, among others, sold legally at this market. Just be sure not to take them with you when you leave the country.

Too much to see. I blame the market on my teenage son feeling ill. He was fine with the cooked food area, and even the fruits and veggies, but when he saw (or smelled) the butchers, with accompanying flies, I think that was the end of his adventures for the day.There is a lot to see, and this market is as big as any I have ever really seen before. Fortunately, it was broken down into sections, so unless you are up for the gore, stay out of the meat area. Not sure how they got the pig head to look like he was smiling, but definitely a photo in my album.

Deceptively cool visit. Now if you want to see something really crazy, check out the Mercado Central de San Pedro. Not only will you have the usual offerings of vegetables, fresh juices, breads, and souvenir items like at the Cusco Artesian Market, but you’ll get to straight up see butchering of llama and alpaca (there was a dude with an axe hacking away at the body of an alpaca or whatever. I too frightened to take a picture of him). The smell of blood definitely made my stomach turn when I first walked it, but the sensation did go away after a while. Making sure that we weren’t just being nosy outsiders looking in, we started to chat up one of the llama head sellers and she was surprisingly very friendly and open to answering our questions. Definitely a deceptively cool place once you get over how shady and dirty it looks.

Loved this place!. This market has everything from clothes, accessories, fruit/veg, meat, cheese, bread and delicious fruit juice and food stalls. You can literally spend hours here wandering around and it gives you a great insight into Peruvian life. I highly recommend getting a fresh juice and something to eat.

For the Cusco from within. Originally this was the most important after the parade for Cusqueños social center. Thousands of people came to do their domestics shopping, eating or drinking your favorite beverage. Also, the nearby villages came herding their llamas or mules were staying near the old houses in the surroundings of Cusco and sell their products in this market.Subsequently, he remained the most important for those who lived in Cusco city. Those from remote villages found other smaller markets, to the present can be seen that many cars come in to sell their products.The Mercado de San Pedro, today remains the center of commerce where they are from meat, milk, juices, etc. etc. and many foreign visitors are enjoying their food.Its location, within walking distance of the main square, we recommend visiting and enjoy breakfast!

gives you a glimpse of Peruvian culture. It's a market that is as popular with the tourist as it is with the local population. From the smell of the freshly made juices to the one of the meat resting on the counter waiting to be sold, to the view offered by the colorful shirts and wide variety of fruits, the market has everything to to awake all your senses. It is also possible to try a Peruvian food court. Just sit on the bench at one of the restaurants counter.

Fun to be here. It's quite an interesting market for fruits, vegetables, huge breads, cheese, meat, juices etc. It gives you a flavor of the local tastes and preferences. You can also buy souvenirs here.

An overall Cusco market experience. If you visit Cusco and have some time, this market is a 'must-see'. Everything you'd find elswhere in Cusco you find it here. Traditional clothing, fresh vegetables & fruit, the most delicicous 'jugos' (juices) , herbs, spices etc.The area where meat is being sold i wouldn't recommend to people who are very sensitive or with a weak stomach.There are guardians over all the place, but still you should protect your personal belongings for pickpockets.

A "must see". I always love to visit local markets, and this one doesn't dissapoint.. The fruit juices, I could drink all day... If you want, you can eat with the locals for prices from 1-4 dollars a meal. Just wander around and see which food appeals to you, because you have a variety of peruvian food choices, but mostly chicken soup, which is fantastic, and the classic rice and beans.. The people are really nice and friendly and helpful and compete with eachother to attract customers.

Love it!. We're in Cusco for several months, so this is our regular grocery store. But if you're just here for a short time, be sure to visit the San Pedro market if you want to get a sense of how the Cusqueños live. If you speak any Spanish, the women are happy to answer questions about the produce and let you sample the breads and fruits that are new to you. Try the Chuta bread, it's sweet, anise-scented & heavenly and famous all over Peru. The meat aisles aren't for the softhearted, but they are certainly interesting! Eating at the food counters is probably not a great idea for short-term tourists. I've been here for months and my body didn't process my San Pedro lunch well. :(

Daily Incan Life. The life of Cusco lives in Mercado Central de San Pedro. The smells, the food are fill up the atmosphere. You really get to see Peru with not a huge Spanish influence but more of Incan through and around the market. I highly recommend to try the fruit juices as they are extremely cheap compared to the restaurants around the city.It is an amazing experience to see a different side of Cusco and how everyday people live through the capital city.

The true flavors of Cusco. We were out early and came across the San Pedro market. At the early hour, locals were drinking fresh fruit juices and eating steaming bowls of chicken soup. Each isle is filled with the most delicious breads, cheeses, fruits - everything you need! The meat isle was not for the faint of heart - I was so sad that I had no where to cook! We came back for lunch - we each had a two course meal of delicious soup and the plate of the day - rice and lentils with salad. I only ate the tomatoes and they were DELICIOUS! DO NOT miss this market!

must see, must eat. Leave all you premonitions behind and venture into this market. try some of the food, try the cuy. Really one of the most interesting things to see if you're an american or european. I have lived in NYC my whol life and have never encountered anything like it. dont worry about things and just get into it.

True market with great food court. A true market, not some kind of tourist only place, interesting to see a bit of local live. All organized by section, vegetables, cheese, spices, etc. Obviously food court is the most attractive part, with a lot of local delicacies to try ; same goes for 'juice section' where almost any fruit or vegetable gets transformed into a delicious juice.

Don't miss it . The best, most colourful, untouristy market ever. 144 types of potatoes, witch doctor stalls, corn, food stands selling sheeps head soup and live frog soup for potency, baskets, whips, clothes, fruits abounding, hideous meat stands and loads of locals, you name it, here it is.Do have a cuppa on one of the tea and coffee stands, it didn't kill us. The highlight of Cuszco. Mind your bags everyone says, some no-good-niks from Lima come and target tourists.

A genuine Peruvian market. an interesting way to spend half an hour seeing how the locals shop. The meat/entrails/fish/fruit/flowers sections were the most interesting. Although could have done without the piles of severed donkeys heads with mouths open showing their teeth! Great to see the locals (and some tourists) eating at the food stalls where soup is about 30p and you can have a whole meal for £1.10. A few tourist stalls have crept in but still worth a visit.

An nice escape from the tourist traps. We stayed in Cusco for a few days only, but the San Pedro markets was our favourite spot in the city, and a great escape from the other tourist traps in the town. You can choose to just wander around, taking in the sights and sounds. The market sells fresh food, groceries, souvenirs, meat, cheese - and it makes for a nice experience just checking things out. It also has (and this is our fav bit) a big section dedicated to food - rows and rows of juice stalls, breakfast stalls, and lunch stalls. We ate there a number of times - breakfast and lunch - and will highly recommend it. We tried the cafe con leche and the torta for brekkie; and the arroz con huevos y plata (rice with fried egg and avocado), heaped with the special chilli salsa. Delicious!!

An authentic market!. If you are looking for an authentic market, this is it! It is an easy walk from the Plaza de Armas. I really enjoy going to markets when we travel and prefer ones that are more authentic and less "tourist oriented."You won't find many (or any) other tourists here ... it is just a real look at the bread, produce, meat, soups, etc. that are purchased by local residents.

A visual smorgasbord of sights. This is the truly authentic local market. It's certainly worth the walk to come visit and see for yourself. Lots of variety (meats, flowers, produce, gifts, etc.) We were too hesitant to buy any food, though. Just took pictures! Way more locals than tourists here, which can be refreshing but a little intimidating too. We came at lunch time and it was especially crowded with locals getting meals. Our guidebook (and other reviewers) warned us of pickpockets so we were careful and didn't have any issues.

This was one of the highlights of our trip. We happened to stumble upon this huge market near downtown Cusco, and what a find! Row after row of textiles, followed by rows of butchers (Americans are certainly not used to seeing pigs heads, entrails, and organ meats prominently displayed!), then fruits & vegetables, cheeses, chocolates, and in the back were dozens of restaurants. I knew once my husband saw them I would never eat at a sit down "touristy" restaurant again while in Cusco. I opted for soup, figuring that the hot temperature would keep the bacteria down. It was absolutely the best meal I had in Peru, and we went back several times with no problems. They greeted us like we were long lost friends, sitting elbow to elbow with locals on long benches. What a wonderful experience. I'm convinced that you are more likely to get "traveler's diarrhea" or other creepy-crud from a touristy place in which you'll pay 10 times what you pay at these little places!

A Relief To The Touristic Hell!. All Authentic Cusco! Think of it as the ultimate farmers market. Meat, veggies, fruits, herbs with a huge fresh juice section as well as a massive section in the rear where vendors cook and sell food. The cleanliness is a little questionable but I didnt get sick. Also the souveiners and such there are great as well. Walking distance from the square.

Love this market. Spent most of our time in Cusco in this market. Great prices on fresh juice (did not have any ill-effects from drinking mango, carrot, and strawberry juice here). We also had a snack of rice with avocado, egg, and fries at one of the stalls, cheap and delicious. Bought a large clay pot for cooking, a vacuum thermos, t-shirt for grandma, some salted beans, and other odds and ends here at great prices. Also enjoyed the churros. Enjoy this market! (Tip- they don't open super early. Go around 9. They close at 7pm)

Real Local Markets but watch your bags!!!. Great opportunity to get amongst the locals. Some fantastic photo opportunities. Cannot stress enough, watch your stuff! Visiting the markets today, someone attempted to get into my day pack in the immediate area of the markets. Luckily the main part of the day pack had a lock on it - now both sections have pad locks. They threw grain into my hair to distract me and attempt to steal what they could from the small section - luckily there was nothing of value there.

Wonderful glimpse of authentic Peruvian cuisine and culture. I absolutely loved the afternoon we spent at the San Pedro Market. It is full of authentic "hole-in-the-wall" food and juices. We bought a ton of weird fruit to try and it was a great adventure. They also have wonderful, dirt cheap 100% cocoa chocolate. Just be careful and try not to bring anything of value. This place is known for pickpocketing so you have to be careful.

The Art of Bargaining!. This place is the epitomy of bargaining. Any goods you can bargain down. But please my tripadvisor friends, if you want authentic alpaca, 100% sure you wont get it at any market in cusco. Those things are very limited and only sold at high end stores (unfortunately). But the sweaters and scarves at still very beautiful and inexpensive. Bought a colorful soft scarf for $5. Great bargain. Another great thing about the market was the fruit juices and vegetable soup. Although its true that the cleanliness of the place is in question, the soup was really delicious. I didnt get sick at all. I ate at the market twice and they gav me seconds. Imagine a large bowl of soup plus seconds for only $1.20. Cant beat it. If you want to know about medicinal plants in the market, please ask for Doris. She is the best thing in the market. The friendliest New York Native willing to help you with any questions. Awesome lady!

Real Cusco. Interesting, original and not touristic local market. Here you can see, smell and feel real Cusco! Take a walk through the market, it will only take around 30 minutes and you can shop several things cheaper than in other markets. A must see!

Best spot for lunch in Cusco. I can’t recommend this place enough. The sheer variety of trinkets and Peruvian wares is staggering, running the gamut from tacky to outrageous. But the real draw is the food. Rows of vendors serve a vast array of cheap and hearty dishes, including potatoes, corn, fresh breads, delicious soups, rice dishes, and every cut of meat imaginable. I ate lomo saltado all over Peru, but it was never as tasty as it was here. What’s more, the portions are huge, and the prices (a BIG lunch runs less than 5 soles) are awesome. Eat the hot sauces! They're good on everything.Ordering can be daunting at first. The overwhelming number of variations on a single theme can be hard to decipher. For instance, one could order lomo saltado with avocado (palta), eggs (huevos), and countless other addendums. If you aren’t sure what/how to order, just hang around and watch what the locals do. Knowing even a little Spanish or Quechua will serve you well here, but people are friendly even if you struggle. The fresh fruit/juice stands (there are literally dozens in a row) are also wonderful. Choosing one seems rather arbitrary, since they all seem to be peddling the same stuff. A warning: drinks are often mixed with ice (i.e. the local water), but it never affected us. It’s mostly locals in here, so you’ll stand out a little bit – but that’s part of the fun. I’ve heard others mumble about safety and/or the relative cleanliness of “street food,” but you’re missing an essential Cusco experience if you don’t eat here at least once.

Must visit this market!. San Pedro was the first market we visited and it was amazing. This is a market the locals frequent... with anything and everything you would ever need! The meat market was most interesting... and the veggies, fruit and flowers displayed beautifully! The woven products were located around the perimeter and you could find most anything your heart desired! We came back the morning before we left for more woven items as the prices were awesome.

A Very Interesting and Lively Local Market. Our local tour contact suggested this market after we told him that we liked local markets. We were not dispapointed. It was within walking distance from our hotel so we started early to see the surrounding area and then went to this market. Most of people were locals except for us and two other Americans with their guide.We started in the fresh fruit section where there were,also, fresh fruit juices squeezed right there.They had a big section of souvenir stores, big loaves of bread, lots of fresh meat ( they had heads of pig and sheep), vegetables and a big section of cafeteria. We did not have time to try their soup but we tried their bread. We had some slices of fresh pineapple that were so sweet. I tried some of the hard boiled quail eggs. The outfit of the local Inca people was very colorful. We thoroughly enjoyed the visit to this market.
Great Market. This is a great market - locals eating, crafts, flowers and nice fresh food everywhere. It was just at the end of the block from our hotel. It is covered, so great for anytime.

Buy your Peruvian wares HERE!. It is likely that you will be touring many a market while in the Cusco area. From Pisac to the tourist trap outside of the train station in Aguas Calientes. They are all selling the same stuff. You can get all of this at San Pedro, for a fraction of what the other markets are selling. Get your bracelets and bags and clay ware. In addition to the tourist goods the sites of the market place are really wonderful. Hundreds of different types of potatoes, grains, vegetables, meats, fishes, fabrics...you can find pretty much everything from the market place. Buy the local salt from Maras and the aji powders. Great to cook with when you are missing Peru at home.

The real Cusco. Where locals go to shop. You can get very affordable alpaca knitted goods (cheaper than in the stores), food (although I wondered about the cleanliness) and sll kinds of fruits & vegetables. A must see!

now you're really in cusco. though you will see some fellow tourists here, this is a 100% local market. have a nice long walk through every section, and then go get a juice (you can't miss the three aisles of juicers). choose your juice lady, i recommend one that smiles while she's shoving her menu in your face. afterward, go to the prepared meal area, and enjoy your lunch, which will be filling and cost about 75 cents a person. be subtle and careful about taking pictures. mostly nobody minded, except the guy who flipped me off when i took a picture of his chickens.

Smells, colours and taste of Cusco. Worthwhile a walk through. Can see all in 30min, food, flowers, meats, locals, chicken soup, food hall.....juices!! Make sure while there you stop for a fresh juice for a few soles, worth it and then continue your day.

MUST SEE!. This is an authentic market of Peru. I wish I ate here more often but we discovered the last day! The food is the best price and with so many vendors the cost is low and just look for where the locals eat to find the best tasting stall. Beautiful displays of local foods. MUST visit!

Great market to see how locals eat and shop!. A must see if you like wandering through markets! A busy place full of locals.. Be careful with your bags etc but I found it safe. The amazing array of fresh juice stores, chicken soup stores where locals eat on benches or standing, the fresh fruit and vegetables and different grains and cereals sold there are a sight. The alpaca and local products there are also a tad cheaper and you can bargain more. I wished I came here first for souvenirs!!!!

Definitely a must visit in Cusco. I love visiting markets around the world, and this was was one of the tops for me. More than just plenty of stuff to buy and interesting foods on display it's a functioning cafeteria! We went here twice for delicious fruit shakes at one of the many stalls, then again for lunch where we got steak, rice and beans as well as ceviche...all delicious and cheap.If you want a real local experience for lunch be sure to check this place out!

Very colorful! Great place to visit!. We really enjoyed this place and even tried some foods (drinks). I highly recommend this place to every traveler visiting Cusco. My impressions are captured here: http://youtu.be/mhJweAbzqP0 ("Cusco's Colorful San Pedro Market, Peru").

Must-see market. For me this is a must-see in Cusco! You'll see all kinds of activity while you browse the stalls. You can find produce, prepared foods, and holistic health consultants. It's also a good place to shop for some souvenirs much more cheaply than many other places in Cusco. As with any place, be vigilant about your belongings. Make sure you try a delicious fresh juice!

Great place to get a feel for the local people and products.. On our last morning in Cuzco we decided to visit the Mercado Central de San Pedro. This is the market where the local and area people buy and sell produce, meat, grains, cheese, flowers and many of the items they use in their daily lives. If you go, and want to shop, take Soles as they will not take American dollars. The market was a busy place packed with people buying and selling, some with booths and some simply sitting in an aisle with their products in front of them. One area had what we would refer to as a food court where the locals were all enjoying hot steaming soup. There were cooked chickens stacked on the counter and when someone would order soup, a chunk of chicken was chopped off and dropped into a bowl of steaming broth, vegetables and noodles. In one area women were busy chopping up meat, and from the looks of it, nothing goes to waste - including bull’s noses. There were aisles packed with beautiful fragrant flowers, stacks of herbs, vegetables we could not begin to identify and an interesting array of people of all ages.For us this was a must see stop where we could see how the area people trade and the types of products that are produced in the area.

Large variety of unique Andean produce with local flavor. Visiting Cuzco's central market you'll feel you've been in touch with the "real " people. All kinds of shoppers come to this clean and orderly market to buy foodstuffs from the region, like dozens of varieties of potatoes or the "best corn in the world." Delicious bread from Oropesa is also available. You can also have a healthy breakfast or lunch for a small fraction of Plaza de Armas prices. The place is recommended even if just for visiting. Be careful with your belongings, especially outside the market.

Local flavor. Not far from the Plaza de Armas, across the street from San Pedro church and San Pedro train station. The mercado is a good place to spend an hour. Apart from selling fruits, vegetables, meats, fish, etc. there are also booths that sell handicrafts, traditional medicines, etc. An interesting place where you can get real local flavor.
